If you want an enjoyable shooter experience (mouse and keyboard), don't buy this game, because this game cannot provide that. The mouse input is so broken in this game, with weird mouse acceleration and deceleration, and FPS dependent mouse input, that the shooting action is completely horrendous. Pick up CoD: Ghosts instead, where the mouse input actually works, not this game. However, if you want an atmospheric story with cool visuals and cinematic action scenes, but don't care about being able to aim at enemies, by all means get a copy of Black Ops. Just understand that aiming is not fun.

I can no longer recommend this. It's not being updated well (or likely at all), resulting in more and more bugs and even performance issues. In any case, while still enjoyable, the game was always rougher than most of its contemporaries. It has some truly ridiculous sequences, plays fast and loose with its weapon models and overall tech timeline, hits you with numerous clown closet segments, and above all subjects you to obnoxious, seizure-inducing cut scenes throughout, even interrupting most missions to make you sit through more of them. I should also mention that you're liable to get shot by your own friends, a particular problem during the aforementioned clown closet segments, which deliberately force you to continue spearheading attacks. It still offers an especially visceral quality from its action, including somewhat improved AI and ragdoll effects, but the problems are just overwhelming the experience at this point.

This Call of Duty Black Ops is among the very best in the whole CoD franchise, the campaign is superb, memorable and among the best writing in history of gaming. The graphics maybe a lot dated but it has that unique the 60's charm into it and the use of real historical events makes this game feels more grounded and gritty than newer CoD games. This is it, the peak of CoD game, an absolute stellar. Don't think, just grab it while on sale.

Call of Duty: Black Ops set the bar even higher for this franchise.  It's definitely grittier than the previous COD games - it has some disturbing themes including torture and brainwashing.  But for those who can stomach those subjects, this game took COD to another level.
It still has the characteristic multi-perspective gameplay where you play different characters throughout the story, but it all centers on one character who is forced to have flashbacks by his captors so they can attempt to extract the information buried inside his mind.
The gameplay is smooth and the controls are intuitive enough where for the most part you don't need many tutorials to learn how to play.  When you enter a unique sequence like piloting a helicopter the instructions will appear on the screen so you don't have to try figuring it out.  The enemy AI is solid - they're more adept at throwing back grenades and using their mobility to fight you (some of them even roll around) in this game as opposed to the previous ones, so it's not as easy to clear rooms.
The atmosphere is realistic and intense - a lot of ambient noise (music playing from radios, nature sounds, etc.) adds to the environmental immersion.  The action music is effective, though there were parts where it drowned out some of what is spoken or yelled so having the closed captioning turned on may be a good idea if you're able.  There are a lot of different environments, from air battles to ground battles in various outdoor/indoor settings, and underwater travel.  
The storyline is decent - a bit confusing at first but towards the end of the game everything comes full circle and starts to make more sense.  But who cares right?  This is COD - just shoot first and learn later.
Overall grade: A.  Really well done game, possibly the best in the series up until this point.

DO NOT OPEN ANY CALL OF DUTY MULTIPLAYER TITLES PRIOR TO INFINITE WARFARE
Opening any CoD MP prior to IW will result in a chance for people to gain access to your pc. 2 security breaches are known:
CVE-2018-20817
(SV_SteamAuthClient in various Activision Infinity Ward Call of Duty games before 2015-08-11 is missing a size check when reading authBlob data into a buffer, which allows one to execute code on the remote target machine when sending a steam authentication request. This affects Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3, Call of Duty: Ghosts, Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, Call of Duty: Black Ops 1, and Call of Duty: Black Ops 2.)

CVE-2018-10718
(Stack-based buffer overflow in Activision Infinity Ward Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2 before 2018-04-26 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via crafted packets)
These are some things they can do even if you just boot up the game and get to the menu:

Old review from 2023/01/10 sucked, so I'm rewriting it.


I'm a huge fan of the [i]Zombies[/i] game mode (really nice arcade game mode) and I'm satisfied with playing [i]Black Ops[/i] on single player. Every now and then I still have fun playing this game due to how challenging the zombies are. In this review, I'll cover the following aspects: Linux compatibility, DLC prices and offline playability


[b]First, this game runs decently on Linux (tested on Debian 12 as of 2023/12/06).[/b] All you gotta do is go to the game's properties and enable Proton by checking [i]Compatibility[/i] -> [i]Force the use of a specific Steam Play compatibility tool[/i] to get it to work. You may come across some issues, and I'll name 2 of them: [u]moderately lower performance[/u] and [u]game freezing[/u]. Because of the game running through Wine (this game was not built for Linux), performance is reduced considerably compared to when running on Windows on a same machine. Also, when a level is loading, the game may freeze and then I have to restart it, but it's not a big deal for me since it doesn't affect gameplay so much. Otherwise, there are no critical issues. Xbox wireless controllers are supported.

[b]Second, the DLC Zombies maps are pretty nice, but the prices can be quite elevated[/b] and some of their associated easter egg quests can be achieved only with 4 players. If you're in for [i]Zombies[/i], expect to play alone. Furthermore, I suggest you buy the [i]Rezurrection[/i] pack first since it contains 5 [i]Zombies[/i] maps; the 3 other packs contain mostly PVP maps and only 1 [i]Zombies[/i] map per pack, so wait for a sale.

[b]Finally, the [i]Zombies[/i] and [i]Campaign[/i] game modes can be played without any Internet connection with a little bit of tinkering.[/b] The devs pressure its users to avoid changing the config file, but in reality there is no danger if you know what you're doing (for example, changing key bindings to load specific maps, thus bypassing connection to the servers but forcing single-player). Sure, you can break the game if you change settings improperly, but it's not hard to learn. There's a few guides on how to play [i]Zombies[/i] without Internet, so check them out.


With all that considered, the game is playable on Linux with the help of Proton, you should wait for the DLCs to be on sale before buying them, getting a chance to participate in a 4-player [i]Zombies[/i] game is quite nice, and the config file can be changed to make the game playable offline. Heck, there's even a [i]Zork[/i] text-based game hidden in [i]Call of Duty: Black Ops[/i]. Good job, Treyarch.

Call of Duty: Black Ops stands as a pivotal title in the esteemed Call of Duty series, renowned for its transformative impact on the first-person shooter genre. Immerse yourself in the gripping narrative set against the Cold War's tense backdrop, where historical events blend seamlessly with creative storytelling, delivering an unparalleled combination of intense action and a compelling storyline.

Having conquered the campaign on Xbox 360, reliving the experience on Xbox One, and opting for the PC version for its enhanced graphics, I can confidently assert that Black Ops boasts the most outstanding campaign in the series. The storytelling prowess showcased in exploring the psychological and emotional facets of warfare remains unmatched, making Treyarch's creation a timeless standout even after fourteen years.

What sets Black Ops apart is its enthralling single-player campaign, thrusting players into the shoes of Alex Mason, a CIA operative grappling with amnesia on a mission to uncover a perilous Soviet plot. The campaign unfolds through Mason's fragmented memories, blurring the lines between reality and brainwashing. This distinctive narrative structure, coupled with espionage-worthy twists, transforms the campaign into a pulse-pounding journey complemented by exceptional voice acting and cinematic finesse.

The graphics marked a significant leap forward at the time, delivering detailed environments and characters that seamlessly kept pace with the game's fast-paced nature. Commendation is also due for the impeccable sound design, capturing the realistic clatter of weapons and an evocative score that elevates the immersive experience.

Black Ops revolutionized the multiplayer aspect, introducing groundbreaking features such as the COD Points system and Wager Matches – innovations that have become staples in the franchise. Meticulously designed maps accommodate various play styles, and the extensive customization options for gear and loadouts showcase the game's commitment to player choice.

The Zombies mode stands out as a highlight, offering a delightful co-op experience that skillfully blends horror elements with a touch of humor. Its addictive and entertaining nature provides a refreshing alternative to the main campaign, adding an extra layer of enjoyment for players seeking a different flavor of excitement. Call of Duty: Black Ops is undoubtedly a masterpiece that continues to captivate and stand the test of time in the gaming realm.

Campaign:
If you're looking for fun and engaging gameplay, look somewhere else. The gameplay in the campaign is, like any other cod game, stale, repetitive, and sometimes frustrating. 
However, the gameplay isn't what kept me playing until the end of the campaign, it was the story.
What felt confusing at first, became one of the best plot twists I've seen in a game to date, and I played to completion just to see what the ending was (i won't spoil it, i recommend you find out for yourself).
Although the gameplay and graphics have not aged well, it's still worth a shot if you're wanting a well-written, dark story.
7/10

Multiplayer/Zombies:
First thing I'll say about multiplayer is DON'T PLAY MULTIPLAYER (on an unmodified game client).
The game is riddled with malware exploits in multiplayer, you'll need to download 3rd party software like plutonium in order to play it safely.
When you play multiplayer safely, its generally a great experience and I will be playing it again, along with zombies.
8/10

Overall the game is a 7.5/10 for me, as my first experience of a COD game.

Call of Duty: Black Ops stands as a landmark title in the iconic Call of Duty series, known for revolutionising the first-person shooter genre. Set against the tense backdrop of the Cold War, this game offers a unique blend of historical events and creative storytelling, captivating players with its combination of intense action and a gripping narrative.

I have completed the campaign on Xbox 360, replayed it on Xbox One, and then purchased the PC version for its slightly improved graphics. I believe the campaign is by far the best of the series with unmatched storytelling that delves into the psychological and emotional aspects of warfare. Fourteen years later, Treyarch's baby still stands out as one of the best.

What makes Black Ops so memorable is its engaging single-player campaign. Black Ops throws you into the role of Alex Mason, a CIA operative with amnesia, on a mission to uncover a deadly Soviet plot. The campaign unfolds through Mason's fractured memories, blurring the lines between reality and brainwashing. This unique narrative structure, coupled with twists and turns worthy of a spy thriller, makes the campaign a pulse-pounding experience complete with top-notch voice acting and cinematic flair.

The graphics were a significant leap forward at the time, with detailed environments and characters, all running smoothly to keep up with the game's fast-paced nature. The sound design deserves a shoutout too – from the realistic clatter of weapons to the dramatic score, every element adds to the immersive experience.

The multiplayer aspect of Black Ops brought fresh excitement to the series. It introduced innovative features like COD Points system and Wager Matches (where you wager your points against other players), now staples in the franchise. The maps are thoughtfully designed, catering to various styles of play, and the customisation options for gear and loadouts are impressively extensive.

Zombies mode is a highlight, offering a quirky yet challenging co-op experience that perfectly mixes horror elements with a dash of humor. It’s addictive and fun, a real treat for players looking for something different from the main campaign.

Rating: 9/10

In summary, Black Ops is a standout entry in the series. It's an experience that weaves a compelling narrative with engaging gameplay. Its successful blend of historical immersion, narrative depth, and solid shooting mechanics makes it a landmark title and a must-play for all FPS gamers. It's absolutely not worth the full asking price, so make sure to grab it on sale.

Screw this game and the zombie achievements. Other than that, it is a pretty good game and decent story. I was quite surprised how I did not enjoy most of the campaign because of the historical setting.

-Gameplay: Pretty stiff but decent at the time. Huge problem was FOV but I could not be bothered to do the extra steps to fix it. Some guns do not feel like they hit at all and lack the punch. Being a game of some years, it actually is quite a decent shooter. AI is very crap so do not expect a lot from it. There is too much ammo available so spray and pray is actually a good strategy. This obviously harms the game but who cares.

-Campaign: I was surprised how good the story was, even though the campaign was not my cup of tea. It is quite short and can be completed on veteran in less than 6 hours easily. There are obviously frustrating parts in the campaign in which you need to know where spawns are and what triggers them. This could mean an easy train of AI running to you or getting swarmed by them. 

I found the levels very diverse in locations and time periods, and it just does not work at all. I loathed the jungle levels because I did not think they were that good. There were other levels that just felt ridiculous to the point that I had no idea what the story was. When your game makes me not care about the story that much, that says a lot.

Also hated most of the vehicle on rails that "CoD" loves to shoehorn in. Very unnecessary but they do sometimes make it feel epic which is obviously what they are going for.

-Zombies: I do not know why people play this mode. I am surprised people are still playing zombies til this day. It is not good at all, it really sucks. Not only is it expensive to buy the DLC to get all the maps, it is a chore, A BLOODY CHORE to do the achievements. They take forever and are not worth it. If you want to 100% this game, just avoid it. Easter eggs are absolutely dreadful to do and zombies in general is very punishing to the point you will be retrying several times. 

-Price: It is very expensive even discounted. It really is not worth to buy it but, I will always recommend to play at least one "CoD" game because they are usually good quality FPS. I would say pass on the black ops series. 

-Story: There are famous actors in this game which really improve the story telling. Unfortunately for me, the story plays around with psychological elements and that might work for some people, it does not work for me. Found the whole numbers thing quite mediocre and how the story wraps up is quite a mess. Now, it is a "CoD" game so compared to other games, it is really good. Probably the best compared to the rest of the "CoD" license which is sad.

-Bugs: It is an old game and it still has several bugs which are annoying. Good luck to you and I hope you do not find any. Mostly is triggers not activating which means reload checkpoint or worse, restart. A restart in zombies is absolutely painful meanwhile the campaign is harmless.

Call of Duty has had a lot of ups and downs throughout it's tenure. Call of Duty: Black Ops, alongside Modern Warfare 2, represent the absolute highest of highs. I will start by saying that it is ridiculous to charge $40 for this game that is now 13+ years old, there are known security issues with the multiplayer (which can be fixed by playing on Plutonium), and I must say that the sound design of Black Ops 1 is pretty weak.


Okay, now that the negatives are out of the way, where to even start on the positives?
13 years later, the game still looks great. Black Ops is just dripping with style. Yes some of the character models are somewhat janky by modern standards, but it was never enough to take me out of the experience, and is only really relevant in the campaign anyways. Speaking of which...


Black Ops 1 features the absolute best campaign to ever be in a Call of Duty title. This game does not just what good games do, but what good movies do, and drop small details everywhere- making you notice just one or two more things every time you play through, making you want to play  through it again. MW2 also does this, ("since when does Shepard care about danger close?") but to nowhere near the level of BO1. I seriously cannot praise the campaign enough, and am going to stop here to keep this review from being way too long.


The multiplayer is also incredible, and you can still find a couple lobbies (both on and off plutonium) to this day. The way that CoD points work for unlocks makes it my favorite multiplayer progression in the entire series, even more than BO2. I really wish Wager Matches still existed, alas those servers are gone, and are just a memory now. RIP gun game and one in the chamber... 


Last, and probably MOST, is the zombies experience. BO1 is peak zombies, if you want the classic experience. Yes, WaW is OG, but you can just get all the WaW maps in BO1 by simply buying one dlc pack, which also gives you Moon, one of the most replayable zombies maps ever made... And with possibly the best zombies Easter Egg, aside from Origins. Really, every zombies map in bo1 is fantastic. Don't listen to the people that talk bad about Moon, or Shangri-La, play them. It's worth it. I will admit that Moon in black ops 3 is significantly better than BO1, but oh man Shangri-La and Ascension are so much better Black Ops 1. Especially Shangri-La, it still looks dark and gritty while mainting the beautiful sun-lit forest vibe!


That's enough ranting for now. The moral of the story is: wait for this game to go on sale, then absolutely grab it (and at least the rezurrection DLC) and never look back.

Temporary fix:

Look up the files d3d11.dll, d3d9.dll, and ntdll.dll on Google or another search browser, and you'll find websites where you can download these files. Place them inside of the Black Ops folder (where BlackOps.exe is), launch the game, and you're set.

Thrilling Battlefield Experience

Call of Duty: Black Ops stands as a testament to the franchise's commitment to delivering heart-pounding action and engaging storytelling. The game takes players on a roller-coaster ride through a gripping narrative set during the Cold War era, featuring a mix of historical events and fictional scenarios that keep players on the edge of their seats.

The single-player campaign is a standout feature, offering a well-crafted storyline filled with twists, turns, and memorable characters. The narrative seamlessly weaves through different settings, from the icy landscapes of the Ural Mountains to the chaotic streets of Vietnam. The missions are diverse, ranging from stealthy infiltrations to intense firefights, providing a satisfying variety of gameplay experiences.

The graphics and sound design contribute significantly to the immersive atmosphere. Visually stunning environments and realistic character models bring the game to life, while the impactful sound effects and a compelling musical score intensify the overall experience.

Multiplayer remains a cornerstone of the Call of Duty franchise, and Black Ops doesn't disappoint. With an array of customizable loadouts, diverse maps, and a range of game modes, the multiplayer component offers hours of addictive gameplay. The introduction of the iconic Zombies mode adds another layer of excitement, allowing players to team up against waves of the undead in various creative scenarios.

The game does have its share of criticisms, including occasional spawning issues in multiplayer and some predictable story elements. However, these minor flaws don't detract significantly from the overall enjoyment of the game.

In conclusion, Call of Duty: Black Ops successfully blends a compelling narrative with intense gameplay, delivering a memorable experience for both solo players and those who enjoy the competitive nature of online multiplayer. With its high production values and thrilling content, Black Ops remains a standout title in the Call of Duty series and a must-play for fans of the FPS genre.

A história é bem legal apesar de ser um pouco convoluta, tem toda uma parada Clube da Luta na Guerra Fria. Algumas missões são fantásticas, como Vorkuta e Crash Site, mas algumas são apenas irritantes e confusas de se entender os objetivos, como SOG. O port pro PC deixa a desejar com performance ruim, crashes ocasionais e alguns loads demorados estranhos. A jogabilidade não é tão boa quanto MW, com armas menos precisas e sem nem poder varar os inimigos através de objetos e paredes. O modo Zombies é mais legal na teoria que na prática, nessa época ainda precisava de bastante refinamento. Resumindo, não chega aos pés de Modern Warfare, mas ainda vale a pena ser jogado.

"Call of Duty: Black Ops," released in 2010, is a title that has left a significant mark on the first-person shooter genre and continues to be a highly recommended experience for gamers. There are multiple facets to why this installment in the Call of Duty franchise is worth playing, even years after its release.

Storytelling is a crucial element where "Black Ops" shines. It deviates from the straightforward military narratives typical of the genre and opts for a more intricate plot involving espionage, mind control, and covert operations during the Cold War. The story takes players through various historical moments, blending fiction with real events and locations, which adds a layer of depth to the gameplay. Players find themselves in the boots of Alex Mason, navigating through his unreliable memories, which serves as a compelling narrative device that keeps players guessing.

The gameplay in "Black Ops" is as tight and responsive as one would expect from a Call of Duty title, with satisfying gunplay and diverse combat scenarios. The game introduced new features to the series, such as the dolphin dive, which became a fan-favorite movement mechanic. The missions are varied, including stealth segments, intense firefights, and vehicular sections that break up the potential monotony of shooting.

One of the game's standout features is the inclusion of the "Zombies" mode. This cooperative gameplay mode tasks players with surviving endless waves of zombies, requiring teamwork, strategy, and quick reflexes. It's not just a throwaway addition; it has depth, with its own set of narratives and easter eggs that have spawned a dedicated fan base.

Graphically, "Black Ops" was impressive at its time of release and featured detailed character models, varied and immersive environments, and robust animation work. The visual presentation supports the game's gritty and tense atmosphere, immersing players in the chaos of war and the claustrophobia of covert operations.

The multiplayer aspect of "Black Ops" is another significant draw. It built upon the successful formula of previous titles with a wide array of maps and modes, customizable loadouts, and the introduction of the COD Points system, which allowed players to unlock weapons, attachments, and cosmetics. The game's competitive scene was lively, with a skill ceiling high enough to keep players engaged for countless hours.

The sound design deserves praise as well. The weapons sound powerful, the voice acting is top-notch, with performances that bring the characters to life, and the soundtrack by Sean Murray is fittingly epic, enhancing both the campaign and multiplayer experiences.

In conclusion, "Call of Duty: Black Ops" is a comprehensive package that offers a gripping single-player campaign, an addictive and innovative Zombies mode, and a multiplayer experience that's both accessible and deep. It's a game that set a new standard for narrative complexity in shooters and delivered a wealth of content that keeps players returning to it even a decade later. For these reasons, "Black Ops" is a must-play for fans of the genre and remains a high point in the Call of Duty series.

[h1]Rating[/h1]
7/10

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Black Ops probably has one of the most interesting stories in the Call of Duty franchise, with quite a few twists, turns and mysterious moments. It's however, not the best when it comes to difficulty balancing, weapon impact and tone. That last one, leans on being too edgy.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Good story.
+ Mod support.
+ Great soundtrack.
+ Good replay value.
+ Good weapon variety.
+ Weapons have decent impact.
+ Good aesthetics and graphics.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Micro-stuttering.
- Heavy flinch when getting shot at.
- Enemies prioritize the player over the AI teammates on higher difficulties.
- You can only stare at characters being beat up many times until it starts to come off as edgy.

Mind bendingly fun multiplayer, too bad activision in their infinite wisdom (comment if you got that reference) decided to cut down on the clients that made old cod games playable, besides that i believe this to be the best cod campaign right next to mw2. I would say buy it but the price is too high for a 13 year old game so, go about that any way you want. (OLD REVIEW)

Campaign:

Right so, this game has the best campaign in the whole series, amazing story and great locations, it reminds me a lot of full metal jacket in a way (same way cod 4 is like jarhead). Reznov and dimitri petrenko makes a return which is pleasant and the whole brainwash plot with mason is an easy 10/10 for me.

Multiplayer:

Love to play with my buddies, the customization is a huge upgrade from mw2 and the maps are masterfully crafted, and besides the audio being recycled for explosions and shotguns its really REALLY fun, dlc is also worth it.

Zombies:

Rezurection is an absolute essential, that old waw engine was very glitchy and all the new maps are AWESOME, especially moon and kino der toten, now my fav zombies map, origins, isnt in this game but this game overall is great in terms of zombies

Overall:

I give it a 10/10, best game in the series, solid campaign multi and co op mode, the price is too high for a game released in 2010 but thats my only gripe.

Ouch, this has aged badly. If you've played today's great open world games, this one almost feels like an on-rails shooter.

Pros: 
* varied maps (jungle, ice, cities, caves, ... . Some special sections in vehicles, with bad controls though)
* graphics are okay for the age, and it works with modern screen resolutions (2560x1440 in my case)
* shooting is fun for a while

Cons:
* very restricted level design and gameplay: you rush forward in a tiny corridor, while lots scripted stuff (mostly explosions) happens all around you. No exploration, no secrets, no point in looking left or right (health auto-regenerates, there is no armor afaict), just rush fowards to next waypoint that is always 15m ahead and updates all the time. the game micro-manages your every step.
* annoying cut scenes, some of which can't be skipped, especially near the end of the campaign.
* extremely one-dimensional view of the world and of war, even for a video game
* gets repetitive very quickly
* no way to change language. bought in Germany and have to play in German, despite operating system (and thus Steam) being set to English, and every other game in my library is in English. Sub-standard.
Overall 6/10.

I am a 49 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

Call of Duty: Black Ops (or simply refers as Black Ops 1) is by far the first game I ever played to feature a story telling that travels in different timeline to made up the feel of a bigger picture. This compared to any Call of Duty game that tries to features a convincingly gritty atmosphere setting is absolutely no-match. [i](No, Black Ops 2 is more of a Hollywood-ish gritty way which is not even close to convincing)[/i]

Gameplay wise, compare the game difficulty to previous Call of Duty games I've played (CoD4: MW, CoD: WaW, CoD: MW2 and CoD:MW3), this game definitely is similarly punishing as WaW, except with slightly lower player health and exclude ridiculous firefight from Fall of Berlin.

Gunplay wise, its Call of Duty, what did you expect? But of course it has some new weapons to play with such as the crossbow, the dual-welding weapons and some uncommon weapons, but noticeably some weapon animation are downgrade from previous game, [b]especially the mosin nagant reload animation, who in the hell is so damn lazy to only put one animation on both empty and chambered reload animation?? WaW did it better than this bro[/b]


Story wise, alot of previous game characters reappear like Reznov and Dimitri while some new character introduced such as Hudson, Mason, Woods, etc. All of them are used very wisely and memorable. (No, I won't talk too much details about the character, because it will be too long)

Flaw wise, there's nothing much besides the poor implementation of shader warmup due to last minute port from console to PC and the OST of the entire game (exclude some 3rd party music, those has its goods for certain gameplay), like seriously, I don't even have a favorite theme or main theme to admire, everything is just feels like a hacked together of parts of story with its own vibe to it.

Overall, Call of Duty: Black Ops is by far the most outstanding in terms of Call of Duty storytelling in both convincingly gritty ways and also memorable way. I can't use any better word to describe the story haha.
Call of Duty will never hit a higher peak than this. The consistent quality and passion on display in every facet of this game is remarkable and will go down in history for sure if it hasn't already.

From a single-player perspective:

* THE NUMBERS MASON! The campaign is a mess. Almost legendarily so, but I hadn't been paying attention. It's using all the tropes in a massively over-the-top manner without adding anything of substance. The setpieces might be intense, but only some rise to the level of "that's a pretty cool idea I guess," Nothing has weight, nothing is really important. There's a rocket in the centre of the map? Presumably it'll blow up in some way, but it won't be very important. You get in the fastest plane in the world? You literally get to look at a static video feed. You'll get yelled at a lot, mostly for things you hadn't done and that you didn't care about. Are the shooty-bits fun? Not for long - as with the rest, it holds zero weight, the enemies are numerous but not interesting. You'll get blown up. They'll get blown up. It's very brown. 

* "The zombie mode is absolutely inspired" probably isn't the sentence you were expecting. It's completely at odds with the campaign in both tone and (mostly) mechanics, but it does work. I'll fault it for not feeling fleshed out. It was clearly a fun side project that paid off, but it could've done with some polish in terms of level design and variety. That would've added to its longevity: as it stands, I'll soon uninstall it and probably not reinstall it ever again. Not because it's bad, but there's much better things out there.

I'm not really "feeling" this game. I've only played the first three missions so far, but I am not finding it very entertaining. This game is structured very weirdly, doesn't take place in "real time;" so far, all the missions are flashbacks prompted by some unknown interrogator using a voice modulator to grill him from a remote location, perhaps in another room in the place where our hero is being held captive and tortured. It seems rather pointless since, so far, all the "action" are of events that are in the PAST. I read something someone had written describing this as a Point & Click game, but that person obviously doesn't KNOW what a Point & Click game is—this is NOT a Point & Click game.

Too, it's not exactly an open world game; it's linear and derivative, kind of predictable. No incentive is provided to encourage exploration of the gameworld that we have been introduced to; there don't seem to be any rewards for attempting to take alternate paths or make different decisions. You don't take point all the time, but are required to follow someone, with no idea of what their specific plans or agenda is. You don't really get to make meaningful decisions.

It's clumsy and primitive, even for a game released thirteen years ago. Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was released in 2004, six YEARS before this game, and it is most definitely not linear, is VERY open world, and non-linear exploration is not only encouraged in that game, it is REQUIRED to be decently entertained...in stark contrast to THIS game.

Oh, and there's this weird audio thing going on with this game where the cutscene audio tracks get louder and louder and louder, making it necessary for me to mute it to 16% system volume (I don't want to get evicted for disturbing the peace).

I'm going to keep playing it for a while to see if it improves any, but I am NOT optimistic. 1996's Lara Croft Tomb Raider adventure, the flagship of that franchise, was more sophisticated and thrilling. This is a retro game, but even so, it's pretty damned sorry.

CVE-2018-10718
Stack-based buffer overflow in Activision Infinity Ward Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2 before 2018-04-26 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via crafted packets.

CVE-2018-20817
SV_SteamAuthClient in various Activision Infinity Ward Call of Duty games before 2015-08-11 is missing a size check when reading authBlob data into a buffer, which allows one to execute code on the remote target machine when sending a steam authentication request. This affects Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3, Call of Duty: Ghosts, Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, Call of Duty: Black Ops 1, and Call of Duty: Black Ops 2.
Bo3 is also included as it does not protect you from any security breaches.
For anyone who isn't experienced with this kind of thing, RAT stands for "Remote Access Trojan".

$20 on sale for the base game is absolutely absurd. $20 for a game this old that doesn't get the same support as a modern game, doesn't have the level of multiplayer activity as a modern game, is just way too much. Of course I bought it, because it was the only one I owned on the 360. I always looked forward to maybe getting the DLC on deep sale, and they don't go on sale for much cheaper either. The standard is pretty much, $20 for a 10 year old game PLUS all its DLC. And that's not just sale price, that's the regular price. Fallout New Vegas and 3 both go on sale for around $5-8 including all DLC for both games, and they're from the same era. Every time COD games go on sale, I think, "gee, I wonder if they're below $20 for the base game or not." And they never are.

Introduction:
In November 2010, the gaming world was treated to an explosive installment in the highly acclaimed Call of Duty franchise: "Call of Duty: Black Ops." Developed by Treyarch and published by Activision, Black Ops took the first-person shooter (FPS) genre to new heights, delivering a gripping single-player campaign, a robust multiplayer experience, and a fascinating narrative that weaved through the clandestine world of the Cold War and beyond. In this review, we'll dive deep into the elements that make Call of Duty: Black Ops a landmark title in the gaming industry.

Single-Player Campaign:
Black Ops introduces players to the enigmatic Alex Mason, a CIA operative whose mind becomes the focal point of the narrative. The campaign is a rollercoaster ride of espionage, betrayal, and mind-bending plot twists. From the bleak confines of a Soviet prison to the intense battles in the Vietnam War, each mission is meticulously crafted, providing a compelling narrative that keeps players engaged throughout. The voice acting, particularly Sam Worthington as Mason and Gary Oldman as Viktor Reznov, is top-notch and adds depth to the characters. One of the campaign's standout features is its ability to seamlessly blend historical events and fictional storytelling. This approach adds a layer of authenticity to the game, immersing players in the complexities of the Cold War era.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
Black Ops maintains the signature Call of Duty gameplay mechanics - fast-paced, responsive controls, and intense firefights. However, it also introduces some innovations, such as the addition of the "Create-a-Class" system, which allows players to customize their loadouts and tailor their playstyles. The campaign offers a healthy mix of stealthy infiltration missions and all-out action sequences, providing variety and keeping players on their toes.

Zombies Mode:
One of the most celebrated features of Black Ops is the introduction of the "Zombies" mode. This cooperative game mode, set in various locations, pits players against waves of the undead. It quickly became a sensation, spawning a subculture of dedicated Zombie slayers. The mode's depth, challenging gameplay, and the mystery of its intricate Easter eggs added immense replay value and turned it into a hallmark of the franchise.

Graphics and Sound:
For its time, Black Ops boasted impressive graphics and sound design. The game's visuals were a significant step up from its predecessors, featuring detailed character models and immersive environments. The sound design, from the sharp report of firearms to the ambient noise of war-torn landscapes, added to the game's overall immersion.

Narrative and Themes:
Black Ops' narrative is a compelling blend of conspiracy theories, political intrigue, and personal vendettas. It explores themes of betrayal, loyalty, and the gray morality of covert operations. The way it integrates historical figures and events into its fictional storyline is a testament to the game's storytelling prowess.

Legacy:
Call of Duty: Black Ops has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry. It set the bar high for future Call of Duty titles, and many fans still consider it one of the best entries in the franchise. Its influence can be seen in subsequent installments, particularly in the emphasis on storytelling, and the enduring popularity of the Zombies mode.

Conclusion:
In summary, "Call of Duty: Black Ops" (2010) is a remarkable achievement in the FPS genre. Its gripping single-player campaign, iconic Zombies mode, and captivating narrative make it a standout title in the Call of Duty franchise. Even years after its release, it continues to be a beloved classic and a shining example of how a well-crafted FPS can captivate players with its gameplay and storytelling.

*DO NOT OPEN ANY COD PRIOR TO IW*
They took away Xlabs, Sm2, and soon will take away Plutonium which are all the ONLY safe way to play these older CoDs.
Opening any CoD prior to IW will result in a chance for people to gain access to your pc. 2 security breaches are known:
CVE-2018-20817
(SV_SteamAuthClient in various Activision Infinity Ward Call of Duty games before 2015-08-11 is missing a size check when reading authBlob data into a buffer, which allows one to execute code on the remote target machine when sending a steam authentication request. This affects Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3, Call of Duty: Ghosts, Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, Call of Duty: Black Ops 1, and Call of Duty: Black Ops 2.)
CVE-2018-10718
(Stack-based buffer overflow in Activision Infinity Ward Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2 before 2018-04-26 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via crafted packets)

Listen - I love this game to death. Zombies is awesome, and the multiplayer will live in my heart forever.

So why do I not recommend buying this? Well, for one, it's $45 dollars. For a game that came out 13 years ago and has had about a dozen games in the series since, this is playing off nostalgia at its finest. 

On top of that, the multiplayer is an absolute ghost town. There's no way you'll find a game, so you're stuck with the campaign and zombies, and in my opinion, that's not worth the cost. Get it on sale if you want, but I wouldn't suggest paying full price.

As shown in my review for World at War, Treyarch absolutely NAILS the aspect of the past. Two years later, Black Ops brings that standpoint to a HUGE high, as this game was hyped to the brink and shows why it was so damn good, to this day, even.

Black Ops released with a fantastic marketing campaign with multiple badass trailers and media practically everywhere around the world. Everything about the game was great, and its Zombies brought the game to it's fantastic final stand, even right when MW2 took the spotlight.
Black Ops had the same fantastic golden era CoD aspects it offered, but improves on every one it already formulated in WaW.

Black Ops' campaign was PHENOMINAL. I thought World at War had the greatest campaign at that point, but oh boy, Black Ops' storytelling is just outstanding. Everything is much more polished and pretty than the gritty World at War. Another incredible voice cast that have high praise shows Treyarch can once again write a dark and surreal feelings of war while also adding onto the era they wanted the game to be in, the Cold War. I was introduced to Sam Worthington here and now every time I hear him I can't help but smile thinking of his role in this awesome game. Gary Oldman returns for another absolute banger of Viktor Reznov again, Weaver and Hudson's impact overall is cool and Hudson's frustration towards Mason and the numbers is such a eye-opening and memorable moment. The entire mysterious vibe that you get right from the start is so interesting, that the only way that I would want to stop playing the campaign is if I got mad by getting killed so many times in firefights. Every mission was unique, a totally different experience from the next, it questioned your sanity, I wanted more every time I played, and when it ended it was all totally worth it. The campaign is a MUST PLAY. Even if you never liked or played the campaigns in the past.

Multiplayer was also great. The "Golden Age" of CoD was so fun to be a part of, but some may say hackers and modders ruined everything the old Call of Duty's had to offer. But that's when PC comes in. Even if modders ruin your console experience, a good reason to buy the PC version is simple: Lobbies. Even if there are lobbies filled with people who fly around with god mode, you can always find one with admins and you can favorite it to play it at any time. I love that so much, I enjoy Multiplayer so much more now than ever. The only problem I would say is be prepared to hear that same goddamn explosion sound effect every minute of play.

Even if I bought World at War mainly for Zombies, Black Ops improves on the zombies phenominon. Both regular maps are equally fun and more challenging than the past, as it was a sort to improve on the average zombies player's skills. Not to mention Dead Ops Arcade, which could never have been added to the game and still would've affect my review of this game. The sheer ATTENTION and DETERMINATION Treyarch put into Black Ops made everything worth the ratings and fun everyone has had. DLC adds to this wonderful game on it's own, but at a iffy price that should be lowered considering it's age today. Not to mention all four World at War zombies maps "remastered" into it's younger game engine, making everything look more gorgeous than it already was.

In summary, if you're looking for a Call of Duty experience that fills all three components of it's day, story, multiplayer and other addons, get Black Ops. Everything from the previous installment is vastly improved on for the better. Classic!

Call of Duty: Black Ops is an exceptional first-person shooter video game that offers an immersive and action-packed experience unlike any other.

The game’s setting takes place during the Cold War in the late 1960s. Players take on the role of an elite soldier, fighting on a variety of international battlefields. The game features an entirely new story that is both thrilling and captivating. It also includes a unique system of earning points, which can then be used to unlock new weapons and equipment to aid in battle.

The graphics and sound effects in Call of Duty: Black Ops are nothing short of spectacular. The landscapes are detailed and realistic, and the combat scenes look truly impressive. The music and sound effects are equally engaging, creating a fully immersive experience.

Gameplay wise, Call of Duty: Black Ops excels with its fast-paced multiplayer and cooperative modes, allowing for a truly entertaining time. Players can opt for any of the three available characters, each bringing different weapons and techniques to the fight. There are a plethora of maps and missions to choose from, offering a substantial amount of replayability.

All in all, Call of Duty: Black Ops is an excellent game that offers a unique and satisfying experience. Its engaging story, exciting action, and impressive visuals make it an experience that will have you coming back for more. No matter your tastes, you can’t go wrong with this title.

Call of Duty: Black Ops is simply one of the best first-person shooter games developed by Treyarch and published by Activision. The game is set during the Cold War and features a campaign mode that follows the story of CIA operative Alex Mason, who is tasked with uncovering a conspiracy involving mind control technology.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lJerWQhMl6k&pp=ygUgY2FsbCBvZiBkdXR5IGJsYWNrIG9wcyAxIHRyYWlsZXI%3D
The campaign mode is well-written and features plenty of exciting and intense moments that keep the players engaged from start to finish. However, the real highlight of Black Ops is its multiplayer mode.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2937734464
With a plethora of modes, maps, and weapons, the game offers an incredibly varied and exciting experience. The game's leveling and progression system is highly addictive and rewards players for their kills and completing objectives.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/42700/Call_of_Duty_Black_Ops/
Black Ops' graphics and sound design are impressive and immersive, making players feel like they are in the middle of a battle. The customization options for weapons and attachments are impressive, making the game more personal.

Overall, Call of Duty: Black Ops is a game that you cannot miss. The exciting single-player campaign and the addictive multiplayer mode offer plenty of replayability. The game's incredible graphics, sound, and customization make it a must-play for both fans of the Call of Duty series and first-person shooter fans.

There's no beating the classic.

Black Ops was really the peak of Call of Duty for anyone who wasn't just in it for the multiplayer (for them it's probably Modern Warfare). A game so successful in fact that soon Activision may be releasing a sixth sequel some time next year and permanently alternate between Black Ops and Modern Warfare titles. When it came to the campaign and especially the zombies, this game had a magic to it that no other CoD game had ever achieved before or since. This game started off with a bang, adding Kino Der Toten, a spectacular map that worked perfectly with the zombies gameplay, with wide train-able areas, long passageways to escape the hordes, an amazing soundtrack, and so much more that just screamed the fact that Activison was listening, and willing to improve things from the perspective of the people who played the game.

After that we just kept getting great map after great map--maps so good that even 6 years later, they would be staple maps included in the Zombies Chronicles series, a series which of its many maps only included ONE single map which wasn't from this game. Kino may have been a staple, but it's far from the only classic map this game provided: there's the equally brilliant Ascension, the claustrophobic "Five", the exploratory Call of the Dead, the classics from WaW (of course), and the bizarre Shangri-La. I still don't fully stand behind the price that they're charging for this game on Steam, but there's no denying that the game itself is one of if not the essential Call of Duty game, and one that can still be played to this day with its immortal zombies maps--they keep on remastering them for a reason!

UPDATE May 12th 2023

Pros:
+ Good storyline and plot twist.
+ Memorable characters and great voices acting for them, especially Reznov (Gary Oldman) and Frank Woods (James C. Burns).
+ Quite good soundtracks (but personally, WaW done much better), plus Sympathy for the Devil.
+ Entertaining Multiplayer mode.
+ Zombie mode, nuff' said.

Cons:
- Gun sounds are something that need to improve, and most of weapons (almost) have no recoil at all.
- Fast-paced video game also comes up with a fast-paced storyline and (some) scene transitions. Everything you can find from many action movies can be found here also.
- A decision to kill some of the old characters just to make us hate the villians.
- Strange and robotic battle cries (especially enemies), also gibberish Vietnamese.
- The bloody pop-up scene when players are injured is quite harder for the players to figure how much more damage they can take.
- A huge TONS of historical inaccuracies and other mistakes, mostly appeared in the term of firearms.

Here is the list for those who interested:

Uniforms and models
- The uniform of Tropas (should be Cuban's FAR instead) MUST be changed, the original uniform with camo pattern is very incorrect for 1960's. Interesting source with pictures (Spanish): https://aquellasarmasdeguerra.wordpress.com/2012/12/06/algunas-armas-utilizadas-durante-la-invasion-de-bahia-de-cochinos

- Spetsnaz's SSh-68 helmet should be changed into SSh-60, since they just start producing in 1968.
- The M88 olive afghanka (around 1983-85) and black afghanka (1991) pants shouldn't worn by Spetsnaz in this game.
- 2nd pattern lifchik chest rig (1988) shouldn't worn by Spetsnaz, the Tropas and the Op 40.
*More info for Soviet uniforms: https://equipment.fandom.com/wiki/Category:Soviet
- KZS camo suit (1975) is worn by the Spetsnaz, it should be 'KLMK' instead (1968, both regular and winter versions). For appropriated camo patterns: http://camopedia.org/index.php?title=USSR

- RD-54 backpack and 6B1 vest would be great additional equipment for Spetsnaz units.
- From all above, Spetsnaz in Vietnam missions should all wear KLMK uniform with proper gears. And optionally either white KLMK or 2 pcs snow camo cover (like in WW2) for them in WMD mission.
- Spetsnaz in Baikonur, Rebirth, and the last missions should wear proper service/regular uniforms.
- Lack of faces variation for every Vietnamese. Also lack of uniforms and models variations for VC and Hue citizens.
- Appearance of VC models with bandana should be reduced. And VC models with a black pyjamas should be increased.
- In Defector (Hue), VC should appear together with NVA forces (but in a smaller number).
- German SS, regular Soviets soldiers, and SAS men in the Project Nova mission only had 1 uniform model, and also 1 equipment/gear (except surrendering Germans that were killed by Kravchenko).
- From the Project Nova mission, Ushanka (Fur hat) for the officers was corrected, but incorrect for the regular soldiers (same with Vorkuta guards).
- From above, regular Red army soldiers are worn M41 Telogreika instead of the corrected M43 ver. 

Weapons and attachments
- You can see the list of ANACHRONISTIC weapons and replacement from here -> https://steamcommunity.com/app/42700/discussions/0/1638662230361512213/

Vehicles
- The Castro's Cuban late 1960's BTR-60 should be changed into BTR-60P or T-34-85.
- Mi-24 Hind (1969) can be seen in 1968 missions (quite acceptable, since we can assume them as prototypes).
- Fictional Soviet half-track in the Project Nova mission. It could be GAZ-60/65 or any kind of Era-appropriated ZIS tracked vehicles.
- German Sd.kfz.7 with a fictional snow cutter in the Project Nova mission (quite acceptable).
- NVA's T-55 tanks should be replaced by T-54B.

Others (including other non sense stuff)
- Different outcome of what was happened with the South-East Asia in the Black Ops universe with out any clearly explanation. In the cutscene sequence, Devs make it looks like Vietnam and possibly the whole region was finally occupied by the Communist in February 1968. Which is very contrast with the reality.
- As a part of Treyarch's revisioned history, seems like MACV HQ in Hue is fully captured by the communists.
- Although it was fit for the scenes, the song Fortunate son and Sympathy for the Devil are anachronistic (pretty much disappointing).
- In Defector (Hue) mission, after Mason recovered from the tank shell explosion, Reznov keep follow right behind you. But after the building's 2nd floor collapse, Reznov will suddenly appear in front of you instead.
- As from above, Reznov also walks into an exploding NVA tank like nothing happened.
- Fictional Limestone peaks/mountains around the Hue city.
- In the end of the Defector (Hue) mission, at the opposite side of the Perfume river should had some buildings and a line of the Citadel's wall far in the background. 
- Also at the end of Defector, Mason should had said "Dragovich" as a final sentence before ending the mission. But possibly because of Dev's mistake once again, he said it before Woods jump into the PBR for no apparent reason.
- In the same mission, Vietnamese announcer speaking a TOTAL GIBBERISH Vietnamese.
- Quite over-exaggerate on how NVAs kill civilians during the Battle of Hue. Their prime targets are the government officials and those who seem to be 'TOO FRIENDLY with USA.' The game are somehow represent like NVA were ordered to kill every civilian on sight.
- From above, Bowman should translate the announcer words like: "Kill every civilian in this (American) building" instead.
- In Numbers mission, Hudson left Dr.Clarke dangling in the air instead of pulling him up. It almost looks like an intention to get Dr.Clarke killed.
- In Payback mission, Kravchenko's bomb was detonated so quickly, both Kravchenko and Woods shouldn't survive by the explosion.
- There are also Vietnam war's video footage after 1968 in the game. Including the Fall of Saigon in 1975.


UPDATES: There should be more units for Soviet troops (gotta thanks Gicombat for this too). You can check them from here: https://www.deviantart.com/fereise/art/COD-Black-Ops-Revisioned-Soviets-Updated-962764718



In conclusion: [b]6/10[/b]
Very interesting storyline and quite fun to play, but also come along with a vast number of unacceptable mistakes, especially in the term of weapons.
And honestly, Hongkong and other missions since 'Victor Charlie' should be set in 1969.

My personal favourite COD game.

Alex Mason may be one of the most tragic game characters i have ever seen, you're literally out of the frying pan and into hell with levels starting in a Cuban street war during the rise of the cold war and then taking you to the front lines of the Vietnam war, all the while being plucked from each level by the mysterious man in the interrogation room asking about numbers, this experience was absolutely incredible and truly was Treyarch's magnum opus.

Seven hours of pure propaganda. Enjoy the life of a war criminal turned Reznov psyop.


[b]Operation 40[/b] -> Attempt to invade island nation and get absolutely destroyed by gigachad Castro

[b]Vorkuta[/b] -> Escape gulag caricature with based red army veteran, complete with massacre 

[b]USDD[/b] -> Epic fake Irish president tasks you with killing random 'rogue' Soviet guy

[b]Executive Order[/b] -> Destroy Soviet spaceship and kill a bunch of folks for literally no reason, just to save pitiful revisionist 'defector'

[b]SOG[/b] -> Assist in genocide of the Vietnamese featuring epic rock song, Fortunate Son

[b]The Defector[/b] -> Continue genociding Vietnamese who are pleading for you to stand down over the radio, destroying Hue City in the process - mission starts off with Woods demanding you set everyone on fire

[b]Numbers[/b] -> Random sequence in Hong Kong for some reason getting attacked by KGB

[b]Project Nova[/b] -> Based red army veteran reznov explains how main antagonist is actually a Nazi collaborator who killed his comrade, demands vengeance. The only mission where you play as the good guys magdumping ppsh into Nazi scum.

[b]Victor Charlie[/b] -> Back to genocide, this time destroying riverside civilian villages, enter foxhole with reznov's ghost

[b]Crash Site[/b] ->  Destroy civilian villages from boat as epic rock music plays - Featuring the Rolling Stones

[b]WMD[/b] -> In the mission with the worst game design of all time, enjoy horrible stealth mechanics while wandering around snowy Soviet base for no reason, dying to avalanche 20 times

[b]Payback[/b] -> In epic caricature of Vietnamese soldiers, get forced to play Russian roulette then hallucinate for 20 minutes

[b]Rebirth[/b] -> Shutter island except you get nerve gassed and kill a nazi at the end of it

[b]Revelations[/b] -> Hallucinate for 10 irl minutes realizing that you were a psyop co-oped by reznov to kill nazi collaborators 

[b]Redemption[/b] -> swim a lot and kill final nazi collaborator while soying out about how he wanted you to kill Kennedy

[b]End Credits[/b] -> Kill Kennedy anyway

[h1]Call of Duty: Black Ops - Review[/h1]

[i]Call of Duty: Black Ops (2010)[/i] is one of the best Call of Duty games of all time. Even after 12 years since its release, the game holds up surprisingly well with good graphics and fun gameplay. If it wasn't for Multiplayer having a low player count and security issues, this game would still be be a truly complete package of a game. That said, even without Multiplayer, the game still mostly feels like a whole package with Campaign and Zombies available to play. 

[h1]CAMPAIGN[/h1]
The Campaign is just as amazing as when I first played it and I've come to appreciate it even more in recent years. Being able to play as an anti-hero character, taking on secretive Black Operations set in 1960's Cold War/Vietnam War is still one of the coolest concepts and ideas for a Call of Duty game that it boggles my mind that it took them an entire decade to fully revisit that era with [i]Black Ops Cold War[/i]. Sam Worthington, Gary Oldman, and James C. Burns all did phenomenal jobs in their respective roles and are still some of the best characters in the entire franchise. 
One of the things I've always loved and appreciated about Treyarch's Narrative team is their dedication to fleshed out lore and immersion across both Campaign and Zombies. Being able to read a ton of lore and backstory from the intel you collect, as well as being able to read hundreds of emails and messages at the terminal in the main menu area brought a while other level of immersion to the story and world of Black Ops. Speaking of the main menu, it's hard to talk about Black Ops and not bring up it's main menu. By far one of the coolest and most iconic menus in any video game to this day. Call of Duty: Black Ops still remains tied with [i]Modern Warfare 2 (2009)[/i] as the best Call of Duty Campaign to date. 

[b][h1]ZOMBIES[/h1][/b]
Without a doubt the biggest reason this game has stood the test of time is its Zombies offering. Call of Duty: Black Ops is the best of the Classic Zombies era, with six original maps, four [i]Call of Duty: World at War[/i] remasters, and the introduction of Dead Ops Arcade. 

[b][i]Kino der Toten[/i][/b]
One of the most iconic Zombies maps of all time. Even though I personally find this map to be overrated in retrospect, especially when compared to [i]Der Riese[/i], it is still a fun map and is a map where I have a lot of childhood memories on. Also, [i]115[/i] is still the best easter egg song in all of Zombies. 

[b][i]Five[/i][/b]
[i]Five[/i] is one of the most overhated and underappreciated Zombies maps ever made. Originally intended as the main launch map for Call of Duty: Black Ops, Five takes place in the Pentagon and puts you in the shoes of real life historical figures such as John F. Kennedy and Fidel Castro. The map is a hybrid of the missions [i]U.S.D.D.[/i] and [i]Rebirth[/i] from the Campaign and is a tightly knit map with minimal space for training. The map also introduces a new boss called the Pentagon Thief who will steal your primary weapon upon getting close to you. I love when maps like Five and [i]Shangri-La[/i], are designed to actively work against you and make getting high rounds very difficult and maintains that inevitability of failure. The main problem I have with Kino der Toten, and why I find it overrated nowadays is that, with enough patience, you could easily get to high rounds by utilizing an incredibly boring strategy that is the very opposite of fun. Five perfectly encapsulates what Zombies is about and I think it deserves more respect. However, with all that said, the map is absolutely not without its flaws. The map's main wonder weapon, the Winter's Howl, is not that good and is only useful for slowing down hordes of zombies. However, that is the only big issue I have with this map. Overall, it's a really good map and criminally overhated. 

[b][i]Moon[/i][/b]
While all the other Zombies maps are great, I'm gonna skip to the final map in the game, [i]Moon[/i]. Despite a lot of major flaws with this map, this is still one of my favorites in all of Zombies. Serving as a culmination of everything that Zombies introduced up to this point in regards to gameplay and narrative, Moon elevates all that with a very unique and cool experience. Moon introduces a few new, gimmicky features like the Hacker and, of course, Zero-G combat. The map's wonder weapon, the Wave Gun, is fun to use. Flaws aside, a lot of what this map introduces is really awesome and I think it deserves some appreciation. 
However, the thing that makes this map one of the coolest and most iconic in Zombies is how it concludes this arc of the Aether story. Moon fills in all the gaps in the story leading up to the beginning of our character's journey and ends it off with a literal bang. After Richtofen takes control of the Aether, the four characters are then ordered by Dr. Maxis with unknowingly sending rockets towards earth, blowing it up. This map does a great job concluding this arc of the story and setting up the next one for [i]Call of Duty: Black Ops II (2012)[/i]. 
Overall, Moon is a very flawed map, but it is one that I personally love, and I also feel was vastly improved with its remaster in the [i]Zombies Chronicles[/i] expansion for [i]Call of Duty: Black Ops III (2015)[/i]. 

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
Overall, [i]Call of Duty: Black Ops[/i] still remains my favorite game in the series for it's amazing Campaign, and its addicting Multiplayer & Zombies modes. Even though Multiplayer isn't worth trying to play today, I still recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played the Campaign or Zombies.

(My Own Review Scoring) (20 Points) Divided by 2
- Story ( 3.5 Score )

1 - Plot = 2/3 Points

2 - Dialogue = 0/1 Point

3 - Story Characters = 2/2 Points

4 - Story Details = 1/1 Point

- Gameplay ( 3 Score )

1 - Controls = 1/2 Points

2 - A.I or Physics = 0/1 Point

3 - Combat  = 1/1 Point

4 - Variety = 0/1 Point

5 - Difficulty & Mind Power = 1/1 Point

-  Technical ( 1.5 Score )

1 - Graphics = 0.5 / 1 Point ( Note : It doesn't Should be a Perfect animation etc.... its depends on Game Genre)
( The Shadows in this game are messed up )

2 - Performance = 0.5 / 1 Point
( Locked at 91 FPS WHY ?)

3 - Options = 1 / 1 Point

- Audio ( 1.5 Score )
1 - Soundtracks = 1/1 Point

2 - Music = 0/1 Point
(No Thrilling Music During Story 

3 - Voice Acting / Theme = 1/1 Point 
( Especially The Russian Guy )

- Value ( 0.5 Score )
1 - Game Price = 0/1 Point
( i Don't recommend Buying it with out Discount )

With XLabs being killed off by Activision, Plutonium and likely H1 next on the chopping block, there is no safe way to play this game or any other Classic CoD on PC anymore. Activision wants you to completely forget about their legacy and go play their newest game and buy tons of bundles.

MWR is exposed to CVE-2018-20817, a massive security risk allowing hackers to execute Remote Code Executions and gain control of your PC to upload malicious files just by playing online and matching with them ingame, nearly exactly like it happens with Black Ops 2, 3 and every other Classic CoD from 2007 - 2018. While H1 is still around for now, it's likely going to be taken down not long after Plutonium goes. The game itself also suffers major issues outside of the vulnerability, including an issue where the game will not launch unless set to windowed in safe mode. Even if H1 somehow survives Activision's cease and desist onslaught, the multiplayer servers are almost always dead even with the client. I would have recommended buying this for SM², but of course that got C&D'd as well.

If Activision won't consistently update these games, and won't let the community fix them, they need to be taken off the store. This and the rest of the Classic CoD Games are practically malware at this point with the lack of updates.

TLDR: Don't buy or play online, you risk being ratted and having your PC controlled or info stolen from RCEs by doing so.

After scoring a perfect game formula, the Call of Duty devs thought it was not enough of a challenge but to add yet another drastic change and taste the water. Result? The people loved it, even more than ever.

Black Ops was a huge change to the game but an undeniable upgrade to many aspects of it, even though it may have originally divided the fanbase, it remains a solid game that stood out the test of time and still holds greatly even to this day.

The Zombie mode made an even bigger come back and is undoubtedly the bets part of the game, it’s so much more extensive and has a lot of content, the online scene for it remains ever so active to this day.

As for the story, it was so good. While Modern Warfare made you fall in love with the main squad. This one made you LOVEx2 a side character that you wouldn’t expect much from when you first meet. And that plot twist yo! What are the numbers indeed.

With Activision sending cease and desist letters to all the COD clients/modding platforms out there, people are now pissed that there's basically no way to play the old Call of Duty games anymore. If you play the games without a client, you are at risk for security/privacy vulnerabilities as the games are unmaintained by the developers and therefore unsafe to play due to malicious software and attackers.

If you are interested in retaliating against Activision after their recent moves, join gamers in reporting the COD games MW2/MW3/Ghosts/AW/BO1/BO2 on Steam with the message: "Reporting due to an old unfixed security/privacy vulnerability CVE 2018-20817."

By breaking the Steam guidelines and disallowing Activision to make money off these broken games, hopefully this gets their attention to either fix the games or green light the clients.

i love this game as well as all the other old cod titles, but since activision's latest legal actions against popular cod clients has made me leave this negative review. these games are not safe to play online due to vulnerabilities that allow for remote code execution, potentially exposing you to malware, trojans and other harmful materials that can result in your personal information being stolen even if you're not in the same lobby as the 'hacker'. (CVE 2018-20817) (high vulnerability, CVSS score of 7.5 & 9.8) cod games affected: mw2, bo1, mw3, bo2, ghosts, aw. these games are not safe and either need to be fixed or taken off of the steam store. 

activision refused to address this issue, while third-party clients like BOIII, SM2, IW4x, S1x, and IW6x stepped in to fix the problem and made the games safer and more enjoyable to play. BOIII, SM2, IW4x, S1x, and IW6x all received cease and desist letters from activision forcing them to remove their clients for games that activision no longer supports.

The most frustrating aspect of this entire situation is that activision's decision to take down these clients stems not from a genuine intention to fix the games or release remastered versions. Instead, it appears to stem from their disapproval of people enjoying their older games, rather than pouring their hard-earned cash into the dull, uninspired, dispassionate sorry excuses of games they've released in the past 7 years, characterized by poor development, management, and resource allocation by a company valued at over 52 billion dollars.

Remember that AAA game studios now are not what they used to be, they were once owned and/or managed by nerds who were passionate about their work. but now, a majority development studios have all been bought up by greedy cooperate companies who only look at their games and studios as a financial metric.

I've accepted the fact that the cod franchise is horrible now, and i choose not to not play their newer titles. However, they're basically strong-arming the few thousand remaining players of these titles into either playing against bots in the few games they have that support it, switching to their new titles or quitting the multiplayer aspect of the franchise as a whole.

Tbh I don't think this game aged that well. I think the original modern warfare campaigns are much more enjoyable to go back to than this. And this game certainly isn't worth the 40 dollar price tag, or even the 20 dollar price tag when it's on sale, not 13 years later. That said, the campaign can be pretty fun and the story is more creative and interesting than most other CoD games, but there are still significant problems.

I think there are points where the story isnt communicated well through the cut scenes and becomes difficult to follow. Some of the levels are just nightmares to navigate. I also think the audio design in this game is poor. The guns sounds like they're plastic nerf guns when they're being reloaded. The gunfire sound effects are also terrible. If you're in a mission where lots of guys are firing at once, it sounds like gravel being poured into a metal bucket constantly right in your ears.

If you've got friends to play multiplayer with, then you'll probably get more enjoyment out of that if you like the multiplayer from the older CoD games. But, there's just not much here that aged well or is enjoyable to go back to in 2023, at least not for the price this game goes for on Steam. 

If this game was cheaper, I'd probably recommend it, but I definitely regret spending 20 bucks on it, because it honestly just doesn't hold up as well as I hoped and it isn't as good as I remember it being on the ps3.

10/10 Story, 10/10 Gameplay, 10/10 Graphics. I recommend playing on normal, or whatever is right below Hardened (it doesn't come to mind atm), if this is your first COD. If not, buck up. The story can be confusing if you don't pay attention, I had to look up a story-line video cause I didn't pay attention. Gameplay makes you feel like a badass when you aren't getting your shit kicked in, I personally love the chopper and boat segments. Graphics look really good, can have some goofs occasionally. Things not loading in properly, popping, or just blurry textures. 
I got this on sale. While it is a 10/10 game, I don't recommend paying full price. COD goes on sale often just wait, you won't regret it when the time comes.

Call of Duty Black Ops is a popular first-person shooter game that was developed by Treyarch and published by Activision. The game's multiplayer aspect is the main draw, offering players the chance to engage in fast-paced, action-packed battles against other players from around the world. With a variety of game modes, maps, and customization options, Black Ops' multiplayer mode provides players with a wealth of content and exciting gameplay. Additionally, the game's strong storyline, impressive graphics, and sound design make for an immersive experience.

Gameplay: Call of Duty Black Ops - Multiplayer offers a variety of game modes, ranging from traditional modes like Team Deathmatch to more unique modes like Gun Game. The maps are well-designed and offer plenty of opportunities for strategic play. The game's weapon balance is excellent, with a wide variety of weapons to choose from, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.

Graphics and Sound: The game's graphics and sound effects are impressive, immersing players in a gritty, action-packed world. The game's art design and animations are top-notch, and the sound effects are realistic and add to the overall experience.

Multiplayer: The game's multiplayer aspect is well-designed, with a solid matchmaking system and player progression. The game offers a wide range of customization options, allowing players to create unique loadouts and personalize their experience. The community is active and engaged, with regular updates and events keeping players coming back for more.

Pros and Cons: The game's strengths include its well-designed gameplay mechanics, impressive graphics and sound design, and a strong multiplayer community. However, some players may find the game's fast-paced gameplay overwhelming, and the game may not be suitable for those who prefer slower-paced, more tactical shooters.

Conclusion: Call of Duty Black Ops - Multiplayer is an excellent first-person shooter game that offers a robust multiplayer experience. With a variety of game modes, well-designed maps, and impressive graphics and sound design, the game is sure to keep players engaged for hours on end. While it may not be suitable for all players, those who enjoy fast-paced, action-packed shooters will undoubtedly find something to love in Black Ops - Multiplayer.

One of the best Call of Duties, for some the greatest. Graphics even when looking at other games seem to be really bad, the story is great, and zombies is just super good.

So here's the plain and simple: You play has Mason, now mason has gotten mixed up in some shit.

Mason is the CIAs best guy, their number one man. So they *check notes* send him on a suicide mission during the bay of pigs to assassinate *my man* Fidel Castro.

Turns out, castro was one step ahead of us; as he had sent a body double to lay some pipe in his bedroom, if you know what I mean. 

I show up. Murder the body double, and my colleague brutally murders the pretty young woman accompanying the double. Yet somehow that's castro's fault. Because my character is fundamentally unwilling to face the consequences of his own actions. 

Anyway, after singled handedly killing 200 to 300 men. women, and children in Cuba I try to hop on a plane to make my getaway...oops... wrong decision it turns out the Cubans *Crafty as they are* have blockaded the runway with trucks. 

So I do the only logical thing, hop out the plane, and run toward a machine gun mounted along the runway, which I then USE to blow up the trucks on the runway. 

At this time I'm feeling like an absolute bad ass who pays no attention to the laws of physics. 

And I'm captured by the Cubans, and they're SO DONE WITH ME, that they ship me off to a Gulag in russia. Which, fair play to them, I am already guilty of numerous war crimes and I certainly deserve to be in jail for all the children I've just orphaned for american imperialism. 

In this Russian gulag, and old russian man convinces me we can just murder every gaurd in the facility and run away *see Not all russians are bad*, and hey why not? I've already solved all my problems with murder up to this point, why not conscript a bunch of imprisoned fascists into my murder frenzy. 

Honestly, this game has you commit a lot of war crimes, and requires you to do things which defy the laws of physics. In that way I think this game is an excellent tool to understand american foreign policy. 

10/10

Call of Duty: Black Ops has aged like a fine wine! Despite being released over a decade ago, it is still a highly enjoyable game to play. The campaign offers a thrilling and engaging story, and the multiplayer and zombies game modes provide endless hours of entertainment.

However, it's surprising to see that the game is still full price in 2023. With barely anyone playing it anymore and no updates or patches in years, the price should have dropped significantly. Even though the game is still enjoyable, it's hard to justify paying full price for it in today's market.

Despite this, I still find myself playing the zombies game mode regularly. The gameplay mechanics and level design still hold up well, and the mode offers a unique experience compared to the more recent releases of Call of Duty.

Overall, Call of Duty: Black Ops is a classic game that has stood the test of time. It's a shame that the price hasn't dropped to reflect its age, that is my only complaint about the whole game.
