[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/42700/Call_of_Duty_Black_Ops/]Call of Duty: Black Ops[/url] is a first-person shooter video game developed by Treyarch and published by [url=https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/Activision]Activision[/url]. It was released in 2010 and is the seventh installment in the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/callofduty]Call of Duty franchise[/url]. The game is set during the Cold War era and follows the story of CIA operative Alex Mason, as he tries to uncover a conspiracy involving mind control experiments and a Russian defector known as "Nova 6". The game features both single-player and multiplayer modes and has received positive reviews from critics and gamers alike.

The gameplay in Black Ops is fast-paced and intense, with players taking on the role of Alex Mason as he completes a series of missions across various locations around the world. The game features a variety of weapons and equipment, including assault rifles, shotguns, grenades, and rocket launchers, which players can use to take out enemy soldiers and complete objectives. The game also includes a number of vehicles, such as helicopters and tanks, which players can use to traverse the game's large maps and engage in combat.

One of the standout features of Black Ops is its "Zombies" mode, which sees players fighting off waves of zombies as they try to survive as long as possible. This mode has become a fan-favorite and has spawned numerous sequels and spin-offs. The game also features a "Combat Training" mode, which allows players to hone their skills against AI-controlled opponents before jumping into the multiplayer mode.

The story in Black Ops is one of the game's strongest aspects, with a well-written and engaging plot that keeps players hooked from start to finish. The game's campaign mode takes players on a journey through various locations around the world, including Vietnam, Cuba, and Russia, as they try to uncover the truth behind a conspiracy involving mind control experiments and a Russian defector.

The story is told through a retrospective series of flashbacks, as Mason recounts his experiences to his interrogators. The game also features a number of memorable characters, including Mason's fellow operatives, Hudson and Weaver, as well as the enigmatic Russian defector, Reznov. This is also Reznov's second appearance in the Call of Duty franchise, as he was introduced as a side character in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/10090/Call_of_Duty_World_at_War/?curator_clanid=42355870]Call of Duty: World at War[/url].

One of the standout positive aspects of Black Ops is its fast-paced and intense gameplay. The game's multiplayer mode is especially well-designed, with a variety of maps and game modes that keep players engaged and coming back for more. The inclusion of the "Zombies" mode is also a major positive, as it adds an extra layer of depth and replayability to the game.

Another positive aspect of Black Ops is its well-written and engaging story. The game's plot is both interesting and suspenseful, with a number of plot twists and turns that keep players on the edge of their seats. The game's memorable characters and well-crafted dialogue also help to bring the story to life and keep players invested in the game's world.

One of the main negative aspects of Black Ops is its reliance on quick-time events (QTEs) during the campaign mode. While these events can add a cinematic feel to the game, they can also feel repetitive and frustrating, especially if players fail to complete them on their first try.

Another negative aspect of the game is its somewhat dated graphics. While the game's visuals were impressive at the time of release, they can now feel a bit outdated compared to more recent first-person shooters. However, this is a minor complaint and doesn't detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

Call of Duty Black Ops is - in conclusion - a well-designed and engaging first-person shooter that features fast-paced gameplay and a well-written story. The game's multiplayer mode and "Zombies" mode are both standout features, while its reliance on QTEs and somewhat dated graphics are minor drawbacks. Overall, Black Ops is a must-play for fans of the series.

Everyone has played this game. It was THE video game and many of its ambitious, bold trend-setters are utilized in games today. Having just finished Atomic Heart, which has some clear influence from the campaign of Black Ops 1 in some aspects, I knew it was the right time to return to this game. 

The gameplay is rather tight and famously one of Call of Duty's all time best campaigns, multiplayer experiences and... Nazi Zombies. 'Nuff said. This game is absolutely legendary and enjoyed by legends. 

While sometimes opinions on the plot can be decisive, this game came out and was incredibly daring with its narrative. Compared to Modern Warfare that played up very real and possible scenarios, Black Ops is technically a sequel to World at War, which was utterly faithful to the ferocity of the worst human conflict that was the Second World War. And the echoes of that game emerge not just in tribute missions or recurring characters, but also the soundtrack. Showing in clear emulation, that human conflict hardly changes. The flags, the borders, the ideologies alter - but human conflict is alive and well. 

World at War is objectively, the best WWII shooter ever made and Black Ops is one of the few games that takes the Cold War setting to its height. The soundtrack is dissonant in its modernity, but it is one of the best OSTs to ever grace the entire franchise. Which is a tall order. Personally, I believe it is on par with World at War's and is just slightly more iconic and brain-ingrained than the masterful MW2 soundtrack by H. Zimmer. But what made this soundtrack feel so alive, was that it wasn't the typical cinematic orchestra with basic guitar. It felt dramatic, but esoteric. The soundtrack, much like the game, was very inspired.

I remember this, back in the day, was the first time I truly peaked at Call of Duty multiplayer. In previous games, I often floated at a 0.97 k/d. For some reason, this game activated something in me that allowed for a steady 2.74 k/d which I maintained consistently and even peaked briefly, at a solid 3.20 at the height of my efforts, only to dwindle back to 2.74 when I decided I couldn't allow it to go any further. The 74u with the grip and ironsights completely melted opponents, especially if you actively aimed down sights while moving backward, which often threw off the aggressive players that aimed for smaller part of your rapidly shrinking hitbox as you faded back like a phantom with your finger on the trigger. Stunning times.

Arguably, if not for ALL of the Nazi Zombie content that composes Black Ops III, this was possibly the definitive and best Nazi Zombie experience possible for its time. 

The campaign is referenced by fans religiously. Even if the trope of the Fight Club-inspired 'companion was in your head the entire time' was rolling steadily (Manhunt 2 also did it around the same era, if I remember right), the way it was presented and done in complete cheese, but with a serious energy - really made this game beloved. Woods and Mason have resonated with players for years, their names, visages and words have survived the test of time. Whereas I honestly forgot how many Hudson missions there were in the campaign (hardly a bad thing), but this game also did something incredible with Reznov as an anti-hero.

World at War was so serious, bleak and heroic, yet tragic. But the journey of Reznov completely is the highlight of the series, nearly. Not just the twist, but Reznov's companionship with Mason throughout Vorkuta and the insane conclusion of the uprising was blissfully one of the most exciting arcs COD ever put out. While Modern Warfare had the protagonist's personal vendetta against Makarov as a beloved plot point, it honestly pales strongly in comparison to Reznov (and there for, Mason's) personal mission of revenge against Dragovich, Steiner and Kravchenko. Their names literally becoming a murderous mantra as famous as the game's "WHAT DO THE NUMBERS MEAN, MASON" - which further promotes just how long staying the fond nostalgia (and well deserved nostalgia at that) for this game there is. 

The story is ridiculous, but manages to have some restraint in appropriate places - only to completely let loose in others. I used to be bothered by the absurd sights of time inaccurate weapons, but this is hardly a historic setting as World at War was. Its a hypothetical, purely fictional and dramatic setting that builds on the real world Cold War. The game knew it wanted to truly bring war-tier conflict and gunfights to the fray. The history that composes this game, while mostly inaccurate, provides an incredible aesthetic, identity and energy to the missions, keeping everything unique, profound and powerfully engaging. 

When it comes to its reliance on reality, it gets everything wrong. When it comes to being enjoyable and shameless schlocky fun - this game hits every point perfectly for its time. This was exactly the game COD players needed too when it arrived, unrelenting fun without shame or guilt. And of course, there is an immediate post-WWII mission that is pure fan service to the fans of the World at War and its a great tribute to everything that made that game incredible while keeping it in line with the themes of the central plot. The fact they dared to do what they did to Reznov and Dimitri, once again, showed some serious balls and willingness to elevate the game to a path that would ensure its campaign would be long remembered.

Many people joked about "no one plays the campaigns of these games" and that is hardly true. However, there were many NPCs players and bad-kid randoms that mindlessly played MP or Zombies exclusively like goons. But COD stories at this time were beloved by those who played them and their short run times were actually to their benefit. A joyous memory is playing through Veteran on them all, going through that horrendous pain, just for the achievements, the clout and to complete the love for these games that many young players had.

The PC version also has some additional enemy models, additional soundtracks for levels and far less choking silence than the console version, much to the benefit of this version. Its a small plus on the PC version, but as a long time fan of this game, it was pleasant to see. 

And damn, when the chunky guitar strums hit in this soundtrack, you know some real shit is going to go down. That being said, the "America fuck yeah" ending is rather hilarious, especially with the final shot of everyone standing on combat patrol boats next to American ships, with helicopters and jets flying around with cool guitar music... only to confirm that Mason totally shot JFK - its interesting. This was also the first COD game to gain some more self awareness and make the player question the morality of Mason's missions, the intent of the both countries during the Cold War and also reference heinous things such as MKUltra. All of these themes and criticisms would be played up further in Call of Duty Black Ops Cold War - which to me, is the TRUE sequel to this game. 

Need I say more? This is Call of Duty Black Ops - the gem of the series when it was already shining at its brightest and yet, this game proved to be dark, gritty and melancholic in many scenes. It is a shame the next two BLOPS games desperately tried to keep that going, but fell into despair in more than just one way... Only for, once again, Cold War to truly make the sequel Black Ops' first campaign always deserved.

But that is a review for another day... 

For now, its time to find that Broadcast Station, Mason!

The best zombies map of all time: Kino der Toten, Black Ops 1.

To me, it's as good as it gets. It was originally supposed to be in World at War but it was cut due to time constraints. Thankfully, Treyarch was able to finish it up, polish it up, and release it with Black Ops, cause it was good. Really good. So many iconic weapons. Layout was a perfect blend of simple and complex and the enemies were all unique and fun to fight. Plus, Kino had some of the best music in any COD Zombies map ever which made it even more addicting to play through and grind over and over. Call me old school, but I think Kino is the absolute best zombies map ever released and I could play it a million times without ever getting bored.

Call of Duty: Black Ops is a first-person shooter game that takes place during the Cold War era. The game is set in the 1960s and features a campaign mode that follows the story of CIA operative Alex Mason as he tries to unravel a conspiracy involving mind control experiments and a numbers station. The campaign is full of twists and turns, and the story is engaging and well-written. The game also features a great soundtrack, with music from the time period that adds to the immersion.

The multiplayer mode in Black Ops is fantastic, with a wide variety of game modes and maps to choose from. The game features the signature Call of Duty fast-paced gameplay, and the new level progression system adds a new level of excitement to the multiplayer experience. The game also introduced 6 new maps for the popular Zombies mode, which has become a staple of the Call of Duty franchise. Unfortunately, only 'Kino der Toten' and 'FIVE' are available within the base game and the other 4 maps are locked behind (rather expensive) DLCs.

Overall, Black Ops is a fantastic game that offers a great campaign and an addictive multiplayer experience. The Cold War setting is unique and adds a new layer to the Call of Duty formula, making it a must-play for any fan of the series.

This game is truely a masterpiece, now please listen to my story. I am a 42 year old father with a 12 year old kid. I tried everything to buy his love including buying him a $10,000 gaming set up including the valve index. He still never wanted anything to do with me. I stress so often that I can not think most of the time, but this game was so relaxing, so much that i was able to relax and think about how to make my son love me, and realized that buying his love wont work. I took a baseball bat into his room and smashed his pc right while he was in the middle of a game of among us, luckily because he never stops talking about the computer, I knew exactly where to hit it. The bat slammed through the glass and crushed the "graphics card". The game vanished from the monitor. Then I grabbed the controller out of his hand and threw it at him, and yelled "from now on you love yourself because I wont. You made me go broke and you scared away your mother with all the slurs you yell at your video games." Later that night my son snuck into my bedroom and lit my bed sheets on fire. Luckily I was able to get out of bed before any fire reached me because I had been up watching my favorite fortnite streamer, Ninja, and I ran and grabbed the fire extinquisher and put out the fire. I then threw the fire extinquisher at my son and watched him cry. A 12 year old boy is far too old to be crying so I bought him a bib for his birthday the next week. Exactly 37 days, 4 hours, 12 minutes, and 43 seconds later, his mother walked through the door and threw a rock at me. She then picked the rock back up and began hitting me with it so I sprayed her with the can of whipped cream I was snacking on. She took my son and left but that was ok because as I said I didnt love him anymore. I stayed up until 4:29 in the morning watching my all time favorite show, Power Puff Girls that night. It was a rough night because my head really hurt. My ex wife was very loud. To this day I am living alone in crippiling debt, single, and 782.6 pounds. But every now and then I will play this game and it makes me feel better. Plus I have a major adiction to food hence my weight. Please excuse any spelling or grammar errors, my first language is actually the language of the minions, which has made it extremely hard to find a job because I randomly start spewing out gibberish, hence my debt. The end.

if your game stutters and sudden fps drops happen; try the following:

Go into your cfg. file (for both multi and singleplayer[steamapps\common\Call of Duty Black Ops\players]) and open it in note pad
press ctrl + F and search for "seta r_rendererPreference" without the quotation marks
It should say "Default"
Change it to "Shader Model 3.0"
Save.

I remember seeing my brothers play this game with friends for hours until midnight. These were the final days of the PS3 before the PS4 came out in a couple of months. Years later I went to a old video game shop that sold console games such as Xbox, PlayStation, etc... Then I found black ops there! I bought it for 10-5$ and came back with it since I'm 10 years late, I boot it up and it was in perfect condition and I sat there playing it for hours leaving my brothers playstation unplayable for months. My brothers nearly bought every pack for it and now since I bought it here I'm trying to get every pack again like the PS3. This game brings back many childhood memories including my brothers. Highly recommend this game if you want to bring back memoies.

COD: Black Ops is out for 12 and half years from now, and I never played it... until now.

For 2010, the game looks pretty good, especially the light and shadow effects, which blown me away. I liked the story and the characters in the campaign. It's not too long, but enjoyable for 5 - 7 hours, depending on the difficulty. Zombie mode is awesome. It's similar to World at War zombie mode, but some aspects are more polished in general. Soundtrack is a banger. It caught me off guard, because it's not usual COD soundtrack, but I really enjoyed it. 

It has some nice aspects, but there are other things which I have to address. One of them is the aiming: this issue is maybe not that annoying for others, but somehow I felt I have mouse accelaration throughout my gameplay, meanwhile I haven't, but the game always gave me this feeling, even if I changed the sensitivity. There are not many people who plays the multiplayer for this game, which is expected, but if you would find someone to play against, there is a high chance you find hackers and you can't do much with it, so this game mode is somewhat unplayable. There are small stutters in the game for whatever reason. In the campaign you can't still rely on your teammates and you always have to go forward and carry them to the finish line basically. There are scripted parts, where enemies coming infinetly and you have to reach a certain point on the level to stop that. For whatever reason, on certain levels some character model are completly dark, but this is a rare problem. And lastly, this is not the game's issue, but the Steam version of Black Ops was laggy for me, but thankfully it's fixable.

Basically if you get into the game's folder through Steam, find the config file in your players folder. Open this cfg file with Notepad++ or other text editor and search for 'configureghz' and 'sys_sysMB'. For configureghz change the value to your CPU's speed and at sys_sysMB change it to your amount of RAM. After this, save the file and you should be all right. If this doesn't help, change the affinity of the game in the task manager. With this combination, I was able to play Black Ops with just a few stuttering.

This is actually a pretty fun game, even though it has a short campaign, I can definitely recommend it to play though the campaign or if you wanna try the zombie mode alone or with others. 40€ is pretty strong for it, so try to get it for 15-20€ on sales.

This review is only for the single player campaign:
An incredible experience, possibly the best Call of Duty game ever made.

+ Good graphics
+ Excellent Sound effects and music (including full songs like Sympathy for the Devil by the Rolling Stones)
+ Good cutscenes
+ Amazing story
+ Enemy AI do attempt to roll, hide, change their position, etc (but stupidly charge at you sometimes)
+ You get to drive a motorbike, a boat, a helicopter, you get to swim and dive
+ Super fun cinematic explosions
+ Experience different time missions between 1945 to 1968
+ Experience different locations (Cuba, Vietnam, Russia, etc.)
+ Replayability value from playing the much harder 'hardened' and 'veteran' difficulty levels
+ Value for money: I bought it for $10 - the game is easily worth that

- Your teammates are kinda dumb, oftentimes blocking your way or, worse, throwing themselves at the path of your shooting (friendly fire is so common in this game)
- Some unrealistic moments when hordes of enemies are never ending. Then something in the story changes and they all magically disappear (Vietnam mission)
- AI enemies throw themselves forward to be easily picked off which is not realistic at all
- On the harder difficulty level 'hardened' - when you repeatedly die the game helps you sometimes by generating less enemies which I found to be annoying (I play the harder difficulty cause I want it to be harder, like duh!)

[h1] 9/10 [/h1]

When it comes to the Call of Duty series, the first thing that most players think of is definitely Modern Warfare, which makes Black Ops the most underrated in the Call of Duty series in terms of plot. Unlike the grand scenes and grand plots of Modern Warfare, Black Ops was probably the first famous shooter game to dare to take the Cold War as its theme, and at the same time, the depth of its plot is extraordinary, creating an unparalleled sense of suspense and atmosphere that is no less than that of the Modern Warfare series.

The game's plot is actually quite remarkable, both in 2010 and compared to other Call of Duty predecessors, an unprecedented attempt that players who love the Call of Duty series but have never tried it before should not miss. In addition, the game's zombie mode is also both highly playable and interesting, and the multiplayer mode is also quite well designed.
 
However, in terms of graphics, Call of Duty: Black Ops is slightly inferior to the 2009 release of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, and there are often a variety of bugs that seriously ruins the game experience on the way to play. The game's obscure plot is a boon to players who like to dig deeper into the game's story development, but this different attempt with the previous Call of Duty series is often not in line with the taste of players seeking an easy and exciting game experience.

I believe that the vast majority of players have long tried Black Ops, more for nostalgia and come. If you are for the call of duty series of single-player campaigns and have not tried black ops, please remember to give it a try, black ops will not let you down. It is worth mentioning that even now, the multiplayer mode still has a certain number of players. Due to the presence of Call of Duty: World at War characters, it is recommended to play the game after completing the Call of Duty: World at War storyline.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I grew up playing this on the Playstation 3, it's part of my childhood so I may be biased but this is my favorite call of duty. The campaign is absolutely amazing, the story is the best I've seen in all of the CODs that I've played (sadly the Black Ops story went downhill in the third game) The Characters are very likable and the antagonists are very convincing. The soundtrack is perfect, there's nothing more I can say about it. The multiplayer is tons of fun, to this day you could still find a full match and enjoy the game. Zombies is also fun to play but sadly you are limited to 2 maps (excluding dead ops arcade) and the other maps are locked behind DLC which are a bit overpriced considering the game's age. 100% recommend you pay if you've never played it before.

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Call of Duty: Black Ops is a thrilling first-person shooter that offers a truly immersive and action-packed experience. The game features a wide variety of weapons and equipment, as well as a diverse array of multiplayer modes that cater to different playstyles. The graphics and sound effects are top-notch, immersing players in the game's intense and realistic battlefields. The gameplay is fast-paced and intense, with a perfect balance of strategy and skill required to excel. The matchmaking system is also very well-done, allowing players to quickly and easily find and join matches with others. The developer is dedicated to the game, providing regular updates and listening to player feedback. The single player campaign is also well-done, with a story that keeps you engaged and a well-written script. Overall, Call of Duty: Black Ops is a must-play for fans of first-person shooters and for those who want to experience a truly immersive and action-packed gaming experience.

It's been said by many people, many times, but I've got to throw my hat in the ring, too: don't judge my experience based on my Steam hours, I've thrown thousands more into this game on my old PS3 way back when.

Black Ops was the first CoD game I ever played, as a high school freshman back in 2012 whose only FPS experience was playing Medal of Honor: Airborne a year prior, and one I'll not soon forget. I was so engrossed in this game that I named my PS3 username after the game's protagonist, Alex Mason. Fun gunplay that never felt too fast or slow, an engaging and powerful story encompassing actual events from the Vietnam War and other operations that very well could have taken place in the 1960s, and memorable characters, the best of which were Mason and Frank Woods, whose comradeship held this game's campaign together all too well. Hudson, Bowman, and Weaver are all good, too...damn, Black Ops was just too good of a time. I'll miss the time spent going back through campaign missions to find fun exploits, the endless hours dedicated to playing Zombies, with its perfect variety of strategies and weapons, its steep learning curve, and its ever-lovable cast consisting of Tank Dempsey, Nikolai, Takeo, and Richtofen, with my friends and randoms online...

...childhood really is precious and sacred. Goddamn, do I miss it.

You know it's surprising how good this campaign holds up today. It's still flashy and fun. The story is really good, and the combat isn't bland (though I could NOT find a place for shotguns outside of situational encounters).
I am not reviewing the multiplayer scene, and played on the highest difficulty (not because I'm hardcore, just because I hate myself). A sequel to World at War set during the Cold War, the game puts you in the shoes of a CIA operative named Alex Mason, who is being interrogated by two men about his involvement in various operations across the 1960s. It starts with Mason's involvement in the Bay of Pigs Invasion, where, along with two men named Frank Woods and Joseph Bowman, as well as with the help of a local named Carlos, Mason's job was to assassinate then-Cuban dictator Fidel Castro. However, it went ends up going horribly wrong, with Mason being captured, and Castro handing him over to two Soviet military personnel named Nikita Dragovich and Lev Kravchenko, due to the Cuban-Soviet relations. Finding himself in the Vorkuta gulag, Mason finds himself working with a returning Viktor Reznov and various other prisoners to escape the prison, and eventually sets out to go about finding out what Dragovich and Kravchenko, and an ex-Nazi named Steiner, are planning, and stop them if he and his buddies can. However, as the plot unfurls, including detailing Mason's involvement in the Vietnam War, they find that not everything is as it seems...

This is a pretty good shooter! Graphically, it looks great. Guns are great to use, enemies are fun to fight, and there's less grenade spam than in WaW. The voice acting and the soundtrack is amazing like before. The plot is a genuinely intriguing conspiracy thrilling, gripping you at the edge of your seat, having you want to know what happens next, with a pretty good plot twist near the end of the game. And of course, there's the return of the infamous Zombies mode, with a pretty amusing map unlocked after you beat the Campaign.

This is a game that I can easily recommend.

[h1]No Need for Cynicism, this is Still One of the Best COD Games of All Time[/h1]
[u][b]***WARNING! This is an old COD game. Activision has completely abandoned these older titles. This means the servers have been dead and have been repopulated with bots and custom matches. There are people who have encountered hackers in these games. If you want to keep your account safe, and avoid contact with these players, it is STRONGLY recommended you look at Plutonium, a fan made server browser that supports most of the old COD games. These have VAC protection and have a functional ranking system. You can’t earn multiplayer achievements playing on Plutonium, but even so, it’s the definitive way to play these games on PC.***[/b][/u]


[i]While it may be easy to write the [b]Call of Duty[/b] franchise off as a shameless cash grab, there are still those entries that make you think back on why this was a franchise you paid attention to at one point.

This is one of those games.

From the breakneck pacing, the awesome set-pieces and locales, the Fight Club inspired plot twist, the hilarious Zombies survival mode with JFK, the legendary multiplayer maps like Nuketown, and Gary Oldman just absolutely hamming it up as Reznov... it's one hell of a package. Even the main menu is more interactive than it lets on, allowing you to unstrap yourself from the interrogation chair and play fucking Zork from 1977. Back when [b]COD[/b] actually had some charm and creativity put in it.

The Campaign has you playing as Alex Mason, an American agent who is captured by Soviet scientists after botching the Bay of Pigs operation. What follows is a legendary Russian gulag uprising, to a flashback to WWII featuring characters from World at War, to a Vietnam boat mission featuring Sympathy for the Devil blasting in the background, to an all out assault on a James Bond villain secret base. It's one of the most insane yet intriguing plot lines for a shooter from its time. There's tons of twists and turns and it culminates in a bloody revenge story that is satisfying, yet leaves you with this uneasy sense of dread for what the next game will tackle. The Veteran difficulty is also the best tuned it probably has ever been in the series. It's not utterly infuriating like titles prior to this, but it still manages to challenge you at appropriate moments. If you're a one man army taking on a platoon of bad guys, you will die often without pushing up and flanking the enemy effectively. But whenever the game gives you a cool weapon such as a minigun, or a shotgun with flame rounds, the game seems to reduce enemy accuracy for those brief moments to allow you to enjoy the power fantasy. All in all, especially for a [b]COD[/b] game, it's a terrific single player campaign.

The Zombies mode returns from World at War, but with more legs to stand on (or less if you dismember them). There's multiple maps that offer different casts of characters to play as, with the mission 'Five' allowing you to play as freaking JFK, Castro, Nixon, and McNamara. The fact that Kennedy has a weapons cache in the Whitehouse like it's nothing is pure bliss. It makes for a fun and challenging co-op experience and gives the game some added replay value.

The staple multiplayer mode returns with some of the best map design in the series and a cool wager system in the form of points you can bet on in matches to finish unique challenges. Having a gambling system in this dopamine infested mode is a recipe for people losing their jobs and relationships at the time this game released and should be taken with extreme caution to those with addictive personalities.

That being said there are some issues. One, not necessarily the game's fault, but Activision just refuses to cut the retail price of their [b]Call of Duty[/b] games. This game is more than a decade old and is still asking you for 40 dollars USD, plus multiple map packs and Zombies expansions that are 15 dollars a pop. That is utter greed. Guess good ol' Bobby Kotick needs to buy a couple more yachts and believes that an old game with a dwindling multiplayer community should remain at an un-dropped price to achieve that. Another issue is the lack of some key PC features, such as being able to change the FOV without installing mods. Also, there's a weird tunnel section in one of the Vietnam levels where the enemies and allies have no textures and are total black voids. It was pretty frustrating getting through this small section on Veteran mode given that it's a dark cave, with dark lighting, and completely black enemies. Might have wanted to patch that at some point guys.

All in all, if you can catch it when it goes on sale for about 20 dollars, it's definitely worth the price. If you have never tried a [b]COD[/b] game before, this could be a great one to start with to see when the franchise was actually trying to do some cool stuff.[/i]

I am 47.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Its on sale for Xmas. Buy it if you want to feel some nostalgia or just want to run the campaign / kill some zombies. For most everything else Multiplayer etc go buy MW2. Comparatively I still think this has the better story. Personally I say buy it while its cheap. Regular price is still $60.

In hindsight, and now that I'm not 11 anymore, the COD series reminds me of the Japanese Gatcha games - a cacophony of light and sound built to overstimulate your most primal senses in order to convince you that you're having a great time, set atop a low-effort, time-wasting wallet vacuum. 

D*ck-tugging propaganda that has as much interactivity as a log flume at a Disney Park, the Black Ops series is frequently regarded in the Steam reviews as having the best story of the COD series. Which is kind of like saying that a square wheel is the most road-worthy of all the 4-sided wheels. Not a single event or character in this game stimulates an emotion by virtue of their in-game actions or dialogue - everything you are told to feel about anything you see or do comes directly from a synthesised impression you've received somewhere else in your life of the thing that this game is trying to depict. Treyarch have correctly identified that they don't need to think about their writing because their players aren't going to think about what they're seeing. They don't have to write motivated characters because they're all soldiers who do what they're told. They don't have to script interesting gameplay because your attention is divided perfectly between trying to discern snippets of contextual dialogue through the constant sound of explosions and shooting anything that moves because otherwise it's game over. 

You perform melee kills when you're told to. You can't open doors because someone else always does it for you. You don't have to have good reflexes or make plans when entering a room, because time slows down so you can pick off all 7 guards and admire the furnishings before they have a chance to touch their weapons. COD became a cultural touchstone in the same way methamphetamine did - by stimulating its audience beyond all reason.

This game is 12 years old, looks like sh*t, and has gameplay is so dated it's beyond parody. The multiplayer is functionally dead because the audience has half a dozen other identical and better-populated games to choose from, and by this point the MP was the only reason Activision was making these games anymore - so there's literally no reason to buy this  anymore. 

$54.95 AUD for a 12 year old game with zero redeeming value in the year 2022.

There's a reason you don't see ancient, outdated, barren games routinely priced like this anywhere else on Steam - it's because Activision thinks their audience are dumb enough to pay for it. It's not up to me to judge whether you are or not.

-I have fond memories of playing Black Ops sometime around Christmas 2010. I never really got truly tired of it as I return to play it every once in a while. More memorable and unique than most modern CoD games nowadays. 

-The story (campaign) is excellent and has many memorable characters. The campaign has about 10 hours of gameplay on Regular difficulty, but I recommend playing on Veteran for a more challenging experience after your first playthrough; I got stuck on many parts of missions on Veteran and had to think about what to do to progress. 

-Zombies mode offers an intense wave-shooter experience, but I don't like horror. Some may find the voice acting funny.

-Multiplayer is where I have the most hours (~300). You can still find online games, especially with 3rd party clients like Plutonium. I haven't seen any cheaters online. Though I generally prefer to play against bots for a more casual experience.

-I highly recommend this game for anyone who wants a great FPS game with a great story (along with the sequel "Black ops 2" and the prequel "World at War")

Best COD in the whole series. Literally every map is solid, including the DLCs and Zombies.  Has a very interesting arsenal with unique weapons. Best AK out of all of the COD games. Decent single-player, typical COD stuff, but not bad. 

The only COD that can compete with this one IMO is probably WaW or MW3, but they aren't that close.

There is a huge problem with this game however, and that is the public multiplayer. It's great that it is based on dedicated servers, but the problem is if you want to host a server in which you gain XP you have to spend like $14.99/month on a third-party hosting service. I would understand that if the game was still in its prime, but it isn't.

There is also a somewhat rare issue where all of your stats can be completely reset, which means you will need to start all the way back at level 1. There is no fix AFAIK, and it wouldn't be that bad if you had everything unlocked in private matches but that isn't the case. Luckily, this game was added to plutonium with an unlock all function, which is the ideal way to play anyway.

Call of Duty Black Ops is a golden age entry in the franchise that holds up even more than a decade later.

Campaign: The start of the black ops story line (kind of...) is a wonderfully done shoot em up campaign that ranks among the best in the franchise. With missions ranging from the final days of WWII to the bay of pigs, Vietnam, and more the story feels gripping and is littered with iconic characters. Not to mention an all time twist.

Zombies: Zombies started in cod WAW but they really came into their own in the original black ops. Coming with 2 base maps and a bonus side mode even with no dlc you're in for a fun experience. With all the dlc black ops 1 is the best zombies experience the franchise has ever had. Call of the Dead being a personal favorite and the standout map.

Multiplayer: Being more than a decade old the multiplayer player base is less than ideal. Fortunately, there is the combat training mode which allows you to progress through first prestige as you would in online. The bots aren't too smart, and the only modes are tdm and ffa but it is still fun enough to relive the old multiplayer if you don't want to venture into a active server.

The Price: Activision's business practices are frankly disgusting. The fact a game released in 2010 is STILL $40 is insane. I bought it 50% off and still feel... violated.

I remember when this game was first announced, there was a [i]ton[/i] of hype around it, and in the end it's more or less well-deserved. Black Ops was a pretty fun change of pace for the CoD series and the shift in tone was well-executed. There's a lot of intrigue to be had surrounding Cold War/Kennedy era Americana, and this game really digs in. There's definitely a lot of cringey "tough guy" dialogue that feels like it was written by teenagers, but that's probably to be expected from most modern military shooters.

I'd say the game is worth picking up, though please don't pay the full $40, that's an absurd ask for a game this dated. Also bear in mind a hefty caveat with that recommendation - and I'm finding this to be true for most of the CoD games developed by Treyarch as opposed to Infinity Ward - the quality of gameplay is just, substantially lower than other titles in the series. Guns feel less satisfying, movement can be floaty and weird, a lot of character animations look bad, the whole game just feels strangely cheap. That said, it's definitely a classic, has a lot of memorable set pieces, and can still be enjoyed in 2022 if you don't look too closely.

The screen transitions to showing Kennedy in black and white, sitting at a table with Fidel Castro.

John F. Kennedy: I said, 'are certain to miss the future'!

Fidel Castro: [laughs] Coño... I missed that.

Robert McNamara walks into the room towards Castro.

Robert McNamara: Prime Minister Castro, this missile crisis was the last straw. We almost blew ourselves up. Now we invited you here today...

John F. Kennedy: In good faith!

Robert McNamara: ... in good faith, to sort this thing out.

Robert walks back towards John F. Kennedy.

Fidel Castro: (pointing at Nixon) And why is he here? He lost!

Nixon is shown sitting left of them at the table, annoyed at Castro's remark.

John F. Kennedy: As I always say, forgive your enemies, but remember their names. Now gentlemen, as I like to think, in the long history of the world, that there are only a few generations...

Noises are heard in the background.

Richard Nixon: (looking frantic and ducking) Sounds like someone breaking in...

John F. Kennedy: Just the storm, Dick. Sit down.

Zombies appear smashing a window on the other side of it, making noises and breaking through.

Richard Nixon: Oh my God!

Robert McNamara: It appears the Pentagon has been breached.

John F. Kennedy: Zombies. Gentlemen, at times like these our capacity to retaliate must be and has to be massive, to deter all forms of aggression.

Kennedy walks over to the wall behind him and hits a button, which makes the wall flip around to show an armory of weapons.

John F. Kennedy: Gentlemen, lock and load!

The screen turns black.

Fidel Castro: Viva la Revolution.

Screen then shows the four of them coming out of the armory. (Left to right) McNamara with a Stakeout with Grip, Kennedy with a China Lake, Castro with a Bowie Knife and a Python and Nixon with two HS-10s.

Robert McNamera: Any last words, Mr. President?

Richard Nixon: Yes Jack, any superlative words of inspiration for your humble troops?

John F. Kennedy: Do not pray for easy lives, my friends. Pray to be stronger men.

The game's ok, but have you watched Morbius?

Morbius is a fantasy-action film set in modern times, which is based off of Morbius, the Living Vampire, made by Roy Thomas and Gil Kane from the Marvel Comics. The film was directed by Daniel Espinosa and had Jared Leto as Dr. Michael Morbius. The film is about a successful doctor who has cured many diseases, except for the disease he and his friend Milo have. Fortunately, he has found a cure for the disease, with the drawback being that he turns into a vampire and needs to consume blood to survive. For Morbius, this is a problem since he doesn’t want people to get hurt, however Milo sees it differently, and takes the cure to become a vampire. Because of this, the two of the friends soon become enemies. The film was very beautiful and there was a lot of impressive cinematography. The voice acting by all of the actors was perfect. My favourite part of the movie was when Morbius said “It’s Morbin’ time”.

On my 16th Morbius viewing I saw a child (beta male) leave because they thought the movie was too scary. I had to interrupt my own Morbius experience to follow the child into the parking lot and beat the child and his mother almost to death. I am currently waiting to watch Morbius again, and hope that no morb-haters interrupt me this time.

"My father was a musician in Stalingrad. During the German occupation, the sound of his violin filled the air with magnificent music - Korsakov, Stasov - many of the great nationalist composers. To my countrymen, it was a symbol of hope. To the Germans, it was a symbol of defiance. Even now, his music still haunts me. The Nazis slit his throat while he slept. Collaborating with any Nazi is a betrayal, a betrayal against all of Mother Russia. Dragovich and Kravchenko were not troubled by such matters. They looked only to advance towards their own interests and agendas..."
"The men and I had fought through the most bitter of winters on the Eastern Front - We were no strangers to the cold... Even now, the blood in my veins chills when I think back to the events of that day... Far, far from home..."
"As long as Mother Russia has enemies, I will answer her call..."
"When the German occupation began, he and his lap dog Kravchenko left my men and I hopelessly outnumbered... Promises of reinforcements were made. Made... But not kept. Dragovich and Kravchenko are oppurtunists... Manipulators... They are not to be trusted, Dimitri."
"Dimitri Petrenko was one of the bravest men I had ever known. He fought by my side from the siege of Stalingrad to the fall of Berlin. The wounds he sustained ensuring our victory should have earned him a hero's welcome to Russia... But Stalin had little need for heroes."
"We have found what we're looking for... Nova 6. The German weapon of mass destruction now belong to Mother Russia. Or so it seemed. Our victory was to be short lived. Dragovich wanted to see the effects of the poison first hand. It was also a opportunity to remove a thorn in his side. I had long known of their distrust. What kind of men they were. It was a betrayal I should have forseen."
"Dimitri Petrenko was a hero... He deserved a hero's death. Instead of giving his life for the glory of the motherland, he died for nothing... like an animal. He should have died in Berlin..."
"As I watched my closest friend die, it became clear we were not the only one's seeking the German weapon. The Western allies circled like vultures... Of course, Dragovich, Kravchenko and Steiner scattered like rats - leaving me to contend with the British."
"Mason listen to me. We are running of the time my friend...Can you trust your leaders to destroy it... or you think they will use it? The flag may be different but the methods are the same. They will use you, as they used me...You must decide... decide what do you think is worth fighting for... Dragovich... Kravchenko... Steiner... These... 'men' ... must die."

While I would categorise this entry to be among the better Call of Duty titles, unfortunately this one is borderline broken mechanical wise.

When I revisited Black Ops, I found a multitude of immersion-breaking glitches, alongside with gameplay on auto pilot, unfair deaths and oversimplified AI; play the Campaign on Veteran and you'll see what I mean. Whilst MW2 has some of these issues to some degree, I didn't find them as immersion-breaking as BO1 and World at War. 

I love linear games when they're done right, but when they're being dominated by unskippable cutscenes, broken AI and pointlessly automated set pieces that the game tricks you into thinking you have control over, is where I start to have a few gripes over.

And of course, Zombies. Yes, probably the best version of zombies COD has to offer, back when they weren't watered down and over-saturated with pointless features. Still not as scary as their debut at World at War, but still very fun. The problem is, CoD zombies can be summed up as a very brief sandbox experience, that feels really empty and pointless when you've seen it all. So when you have unlocked every door, power up and get the weapons you want - that's it, you've basically finished this mode until you run out of auto revives and/or get trapped into a corner. I prefer Campaigns, since it is where most of the focus was invested in and it also represents the game as a whole.

It's not true that Call of Duty is the Fast Food of First Person Shooters, at least in it's earlier days. But games like Black Ops makes it hard for me to consider it being the best way to experience Call of Duty.

Bon, ayant commencé la Licence depuis Call of Duty 2 soit en 2005, déjà sur Xbox 360, je trouvais BO1 franchement très moyen, le jeu était franchement pas terrible techniquement (même si la direction artistique et les effets en général étaient bons), et puis le jeu en lui même était très moyen (surtout après MW2 mais surtout World at War qui reste à ce jour le meilleur de la Série). Que vaut cette version PC, bah mon avis à très peu changé, le jeu reste très moyen mais franchement il est à la limite d'être franchement pas foufou.
Laissez de côté la nostalgie de côté et notez le jeu objectivement, parce que y'a des choses que vous laissez passer alors que c'est clairement mauvais. Bref, je m'égare, passons au vif du sujet.

Je vais déjà commencer par les points positifs du jeu et puis ensuite j'enchaînerais bien évidemment sur les aspects négatifs du jeu.

Déjà en point positif, ça ne change absolument pas, c'est la Campagne donc le Solo. J'ai toujours adoré la Campagne de BO1, le côté Psychologique et le côté horreur tout de même de la Guerre (même si World at War lui sur le côté horreur et la violence de la Guerre est indétrônable), est vachement bon. Le personnage d'Alex Mason est franchement intéressant de même que ses coéquipiers notamment Frank Woods. Y'a énormément de missions cultes sur le jeu, la Mission en Arctique ou on incarne Reznov (il est de retour bien entendu) est toujours excellente, les Missions aux Viet Nâm et aux Laos sont incroyables, la Mission à Vorkouta est elle aussi sensationnelle...Bref, vous l'aurez compris, rien à dire vis à vis de la campagne, elle est toujours incroyable et fait partie selon moi des meilleures Campagne de la Série, les Renseignements aussi que vous pouvez ramasser sont intéressants également à faire car ceux-ci vous pourrez les lires au Menu Principal et cela vous apportera des informations intéressantes sur le Scénario et puis également évoquera énormément des faits réels sur ce qu'il s'est passé sur différents conflits durant La Guerre Froide (Viet Nâm, Laos...).

La Bande Son, donc l'ambiance globale du jeu, le bruits des armes, explosion etc et puis évidemment les Musiques, il me semble que c'est le même Compositeur que celui de World at War soit Sean Murray il me semble et rien à redire, les Musiques sont franchement excellentes (mention spéciale à une Mission en particulier qui reprends des Musiques de World at War).

Le gameplay en général est agréable, on connait, c'est classique et c'est du Call of Duty (à une exception près mais j'en reparlerais plus tard) moi qui adore le gameplay d'MW3 (car assez lent) et bien BO1 c'est exactement pareil, j'ai même l'impression que le gameplay de BO1 est plus rapide que celui d'MW3.

Le recul des armes, alors ça, c'est un très bon point, j'avoue avoir oublié que la majorité des armes ont un recul vachement important, surtout lorsque vous plombez avec, les armes de BO1 donc un jeu sortit en 2010 ont quand même plus d'impact que celles de Vanguard ou de Cold War qui eux sont sortis en 2020 et 2021, c'est ridicule. 
Les armes ont principalement un recul horizontal lorsque vous plombez avec les armes.


Je vais pouvoir vous parlez désormais des points négatifs du jeu.


Le Multijoueur est de base à mon sens très moyen (malgré effectivement de bons points comme les maps (sauf certaines franchement à chier comme: Cracked, Crisis, Array et Radiation), les Explosifs au moins ne sont pas efficaces si vous avez l'Atout Gilet Pare Balles (ce qui est excellent), le Multi est plutôt bien équilibré (sauf évidemment quelques armes broken (notamment la Commando et la Galil) mais sincèrement, le Multi est injouable en tout cas sur PC, on tombe que contre des Prestiges Max qui TryHard et qui jouent évidemment avec leurs Méta (sans parler des rats qui cheats avec leurs magnifiques Back-Track où tu peux rien faire en duel évidemment) et puis les Serveurs en général sont vraiment pas dingues du tout.
Les Streaks sont quand même broken et assez simple à avoir (BlackBird, Huey (Mitrailleur d'Hélico), Hind, Chiens, Hélico de Combat (vous pilotez un Hind et vous pouvez tirer avec vos Mitrailleuses Gatling et vos Roquettes).

Je suis désolé mais, le Zombies de BO1 est franchement pas terrible (je précise que j'adore le Zombies et que j'y joue depuis World at War et que j'ai fais les Secrets de toutes les maps de BO3 et celles de BO4 y compris aussi quelques unes de BO2 donc je suis légitime pour critiquer le Zombies), enlevez la Nostalgie de côté et soyez objectif, sans parler des maps qui sont moyennes voire dégeulasses (mention spéciale à Moon qui est UNE des pires maps de l'Histoire)
 J'ai évoqué le Gameplay en point positif ci dessus mais le Gameplay en Zombies n'est pas adapté je trouve, il est beaucoup trop lent pour un mode Zombies, sans parler du problème majeure qui fait que je ne comprends pas pourquoi le Zombies de BO1 est acclamé par les Hardcore Gamers, les Doubles Claques des Zombies sont tout bonnement insupportable, tu ne peux absolument rien faire, et ce dès la Manche 1. Sur World at War il y'avait le problème des Zombies "qui t'aspiraient" quand on leur mettait un coup de couteau, mais tu pouvais contrer ceci en reculant et en mettant un coup de couteau ce qui empêchait le coup de couteau Commando (ce qui provoquait le "Zombies qui t'aspirais"), mais là sur BO1, de base tu as l'effet Commando lors de ton coup de Couteau donc tu ne peux pas mettre un coup de couteau en reculant, ce qui par conséquent empêche de contrer les Doubles Claques, et pardonnez moi mais ça nique complètement le Zombies de BO1 selon moi.
Pour ceux qui l'auraient pas compris, je reproche principalement au Zombies de BO1 de désavantager en permanence le joueur (ce qui est franchement à chier car le Zombies de BO1 est UN des plus difficiles de la Licence pas parce que tu dois le maîtriser, mais parce que le jeu te désavantage en permanence et avantage les Zombies ce qui est l'inverse de BO3 ou de BO4 par exemple qui eux justement te demandes de maîtriser la Map et les Mécaniques du jeu global)
  Sans parler aussi des armes de BO1 (tout comme celles de BO2) qui ne font aucun dégâts même quand tu les améliores, RPK Améliorée ou HK-21 Améliorée ne servent plus à rien à partir des Manches 16-17 donc les Zombies sont des Sacs à PV, y'a réellement que quelques armes ultra efficaces comme le Thundergun (donc Wonder Weapon), le Laser dans mes souvenirs est le dernier CoD ou il est efficace, la Commando ainsi que la Galil sont très efficace aussi.
C'est selon moi UN des pires Zombies de chez Treyarch (oublions Vanguard lui est à part, le Zombies de BO1 est cependant évidemment moins dégeulasse que celui de BO2, mais BO3 et BO4 sont les meilleurs et de très loin)

Dernier point négatif et c'est UN des plus importants, c'est l'optimisation, elle est franchement calamiteuse, déjà que le jeu même sur PC est moche (les effets et la DA passe bien), j'ai dû désactiver les Ombres et dégager l'Anti-Aliasing ainsi que l'Anticrénelage tellement je perdais d'FPS (même en bloquant mes FPS à 60 j'ai parfois des chutes d'FPS). 
Le jeu souffre de bug dans la Campagne Solo, dans 2 Missions vous aurez un QTE ou vous devrez appuyer sur une touche rapidement pour que le Script fonctionne, ouais, bah ça fonctionne pas, il faudra appuyer "rapidement" sur: Clique Gauche + Clique Droit + F (ou c'est E, je m'en souviens pas), remercions l'optimisation une fois de plus.

Pour conclure, je n'ai jamais compris l'admiration des joueurs vis à vis de Black Ops, enfin si, c'est la Nostalgie, mais le jeu est très loin d'être un chef d'oeuvre, je vais être cash, je lui mets un 11/20, c'est la Campagne qui sauve entièrement le jeu d'être mauvais, alors oui, ça risque de choquer les Hardcore Gamers qui manquent d'objectivité sur BO1 mais bon c'est pas grave. 
Le jeu vaut 40 € et 20 € en Promo (je l'ai acheté en Promo), bah franchement évitez le, je le déconseille fortement (en tout cas tant qu'il sera pas en dessous de 10€).

11/20.

This isn’t a bad game but multiplayer is just a mess. First off it’s server based and the only “normal” game mode available is strictly nuketown TDM, the rest of the game modes are either modded, crouch only, hardcore with strict admins who can ban you for any reason and not to mention dead. No official matchmaking for zombies to meet new people so you have to play with people only on your friends list. If you want this game you might as well just buy it for ps3 or Xbox because it’s 1 cheaper (you can get black ops 1 and 2 for ps3 for like 10$), 2 has a bigger community and has more modes available (including search and destroy). 3 zombies has an official matchmaking so you don’t have to invite friends only.
But don’t get me wrong this is a fun game and worth getting if you have a console. Multiplayer is fun, zombies is fun and the campaign is fun I honestly can’t complain about the game itself.

Edit: ok the zombies does have an active matchmaking I couldn't find the button lol.

Black Ops isn't just a game to me, but a game that I grew up with when I first started playing it on the PS3 console when the PS4 came out. I gotta say, I love strolling down memory lane, this game is my memory of how I started playing the COD franchise for the first time. I loved playing the Campaign, Multiplayer, and Zombie modes. All three were a dream come true when I finally played with others like me who kept continuing to play this game. The Campaign Story will always be great to me, the Multiplayer mode would always be one of the best modes added with the weapons that I loved using. And finally for the Zombie mode, one of my dearest and favorite COD Game Modes, I have to say that it always takes me back when I would play with others online and remember the challenges of how many rounds just one person or more people can do. if you are new to the COD Franchise, this would be the game to help new comers play as they will, I will always love this game and I will never let my memory of this game fade away anymore.

FULL REVIEW, including multiplayer, zombies, and more: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2855776413
(I'd put it all here but word limit prevents me from doing so).

Campaign Review [LIGHT SPOILERS BELOW]

Just played the campaign for the first time. Wow. What a movie. I've previously played CoD 2 and the Modern Warfare trilogy, and this was simply wow. It may not be as fair of a comparison since I've played the other games to death and this is new, but I think this might be the best movie campaign they've released thus far. CoD 4 had a great story, but it was still half-rooted in the military shooter niche of its predecessor (that Medal of Honor heritage), so it was lacking in unique set pieces (probably had a smaller budget too). MW2 had fantastic action movie moments and some of the best set pieces, but the writing connecting things was pretty weak, full of holes. MW3 was not that original; it had a satisfying conclusion but felt more like a "best hits" album of moments from the first two games.

Black Ops has the complete package: a brilliant plot featuring a mind-bending, chilling story, great direction, fantastic acting, a protagonist who finally speaks (that's a first for this series!), good soundtrack, and it's got great exotic locations. Most prominently featured is 'nam, which was one of the key draws of the game for me, and it definitely lives up to my expectations. Those moments are awesome, but there's plenty of variety in level design from Soviet bases in the freezing tundra to a prison riot escape in the desert.

I really like some of the new guns too like the explosive crossbow bolt which is pretty f***ing awesome, and some scenes felt inspired by Terminator 2 and Commando, which brought a huge grin to my face. In fact, that was a feeling I had a lot playing through this delight of a game/movie. What I love about this entry is that any trappings of the once purely military shooter game have been shed, and the creative team had the freedom to really just make whatever movie they wanted, and they did a wonderful job at that. They don't feel constrained to follow the typical, cliche Call of Duty script (although that's not to say moments don't exist that vaguely mirror their counterparts in the other CoD games).

The graphics are so gorgeously realistic too that never once did I feel I was playing a game trying to be a movie; I was just in the movie, as if I was in the theaters. When they played an FMV at the end, I could tell that was a real human woman, but otherwise it looked identical to the game's cutscenes. It's that good. There's impeccable attention to detail from the insects and rats crawling inside VC tunnels to the sound design intentionally muffling bullet fire when you're wearing a hazmat suit, mimicking what it would sound like in real life.

I can't ignore the lovely inclusion of a Rolling Stones song either, Sympathy for the Devil, though fear not, Fortunate Son still makes its obligatory appearance too.

All in all, an awesome campaign, arguably the best Call of Duty one so far, and one I thoroughly enjoyed.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

CALL OF DUTY STEAM VETERAN JOURNEY
doing all cods on veteran in order. Honestly, this was a very poor experience on veteran. Many areas where you would be stuck on objects or where there was infinite spawning enemies again (which werent around for the past few games). Dont even get me started on the jeep turret section on the second last level. While the story is excellent and this game is worth it for custom lobbies and zombies, this shit on veteran was the worst experience yet. And no its not the hardest, i mean in terms of quality. You will die in sections with no real say or control as you can die before even going around a corner, i think its a physique issue tbh. At least the timed sections were pretty easy but this makes me worried to do BO2 since i had little fun here. Some areas felt like it had poor lighting as well, it was struggle to see some shots.

Tips:
- On the turret section on the second last level spam the grenade launcher function and pick a god.
- Some checkpoint areas wont hit until you die and re-do an area.
- Snipe with the helicopter.
- Run up and retreat to make allies advance, but dont TRUST BO1 allies to even clear sections right next to them
- Try to stay back and minimise enemies of infinite reinforcements before moving up and then retreating.
- Have a rocket launcher on backup when possible, one gun with a scope or decent aim is all you ever need
- Dont buy if not on sale

I am only reviewing the single player campaign. I am not reviewing any multiplayer component of the game which I played 12 years ago or whenever this game originally came out on XBOX 360. They were good then. I don't know what they're like now. So, if somehow you don't know about this game or want to know what multiplayer is like now, don't read this for that information.

I recently randomly decided to play this again. I never played this on PC, but I finished it when it came out originally (what, in 2010?) on XBOX 360.
I mainly just wanted wanted to write this because of two (maybe three) reasons. One I was playing the original Modern Warfare games before, all of which are middle of the road and not particularly great single player campaigns, but their fine first person shooters. Most people play them for multiplayer which is not something I am big on and I'm not interested in playing a dumb pretend military shooter where kids cuss at each other and talk about how realistic it is. It's not. It's Hollywood's version of war. It's pretty dramatic and unrealistic.
Anyway, the other reason is that all of the original Modern Warfare games have pretty middle of the road and simplistic stories with particularly competent shooting mechanics that they don't entirely let you use because most of those single player campaigns are mainly just shooting galleries with QTEs. They also, all three of them, crash my computer causing it to reboot at a certain point in the campaign. All three of those games still cause this. They're really poorly made games that made millions. It's quite shocking they're so popular since they're so badly programmed, but I have my own theories as to their popularity. That's a different discussion, though.
So, I remembered liking this one, but I was curious if it still holds up. Maybe it's not as good as I remembered. Maybe it has more QTEs and less game play then I recalled? I played all the original Modern Warfare games and it just made me question whether this one was actually as good as I remembered it being because those don't really let you play all that much.
Well, I can confirm this game still holds up very well. It's very cinematic, yes, but the missions you go on are well done and feel strategic in play. They don't just feel like shooting galleries, like other Modern Warfare games, and the story is probably too interesting for the game that's being made by a mega-corporation that only cares about profits that get funneled into Bobby Kotick's mouth. It's still a really fun story that makes sense for the era it's set in. This game will go down, at least for me, in a sadly growing list of phenomenally written story driven military game campaigns that no one will remember in 10-20 years.
The mechanics are good in all Modern Warfare games, but they are good in this as well. So, there's that.
I remember finding this game to be a really fun, exciting, story based experience when I originally played it so I am happy to find that that fact still remains and I would STILL highly recommend the single player campaign for this game. It is STILL the only modern warfare game I have played with a single player campaign that I think is any good and worth replaying.

That being said I do recommend waiting for a sale. Not because it wasn't worth full price originally even, but because the game has been out for over 10 years. They DO put their games on deep sale when there are steam sales so I do recommend waiting for one before you buy any Activision game. You could probably get this for 10$ maybe. I don't know exactly- I bought all the Modern Warfare games years ago now on a sale where they were all really cheap and I have been slowly playing the ones I have no interest in and also next I want to play the next Black Ops because I never played that.

So, anyway, this game is still great, and still looks great at 1080p, but it is old so just wait for a sale and buy it then. The single player game is still very good and worth playing.

Hello, This is my review for Call of Duty: Black Ops. 

Chapter One: Campaign.
The black ops campaign is one of the best I've ever played talking story. Amazing writing, great characters, and you don't need to play the previous game to understand. (But I do recommend playing World at War because its also a great campaign)  For gameplay, its very fun but don't expect something revolutionary, It's fun but its not the greatest gameplay ever.

Chapter Two: Multiplayer
Plain and simple, its completely dead. Even if some people are still playing I don't recommend playing because of security risks. If you really wan't to play it there are community made server browsers to help with that. Other than that its good and fun but not really SUPER amazing.

Chapter Three: Zombies
Ok ok, before I get into this I will admit I have a huge bias because I LOVE Call of Duty: Zombies. But Black Ops Zombies is great, it's a lot of fun, more polished and less buggy than World at War. The maps include classics like Kino Der Toten, fend off the undead in an abandoned WW2 theatre turned Nazi facility and a great beginner map. Five, Play as Kennedy, Nixon, MacNamara, or Castro and kill hordes of zombies in the pentagon. (We are now getting into DLC maps so they aren't free) DLC: Escalation, Call of the Dead. Fight more hordes in Sibera as Micheal Rooker, Danny Trejo, Sarah Michelle Gellar or Robert Englund and fight an undead George Romero. (and he is like a boss zombie with LOTS of health so don't even try fighting him and don't damage him at all, trust me.) DLC: First strike, Ascension. Kill zombies in a russian cosmodrone overrun by the undead. TIP: at around round 9 or 10 monkeys will spawn and steal your perks, don't let them get the perk machines! DLC: Annihilation, Shangri-La. Place unknown, the undead have overrun this mythical city with origins unknown, try to survive as long as you can! TIP: when buying doors, certain areas might be booby trapped. Monkeys are also present on this map. DLC: Rezzurection, Moon. That's right, zombies on the moon. Find an old abandoned station on the moon, riddled with zombies. Find the power and survive for as long as you can. TIP: Certain portions of the map will be excavated at certain times after turning the power on. It won't remove it, it will just block your path. This DLC also comes with all of the previous zombies maps. Nacht Der Untoten: Survive in an WW2 bunker on an abandoned airfield. Verruckt: WW2 German insane asylum with sick experiments done in the facility. (Probably the scariest map in zombies) Shi-No-Numa: WW2 Japenese facility. Swampy outside, and random perk locations. Der Riese: The facility where it all began, first map to have an option to upgrade your guns for 5,000 points. Link the teleporters to the mainframe to unlock it.

Conclusion:
Campaign: 8/10, it's very much worth your time.
Multiplayer: 1/10, great multiplayer, but it’s mostly dead. There are modded server browsers which makes it playable, but do not play the steam version, if you do it’s a big security risk.
Zombies: 9/10. amazing zombies, not the best, not perfect, but its an amazing time. It's lots of fun with co-op but just as much in solo.

NOTE: I play only these games for the campaign

This campaign is... awful

The story makes 0 sense, it just throws you around all over the place facing a bunch of evil russians. The missions sometimes are so scripted it's like playing a rail shooter. It feels like playing one of those old arcade games, I just use a mouse and keyboard instead of a light gun. The game gives you basically unlimited ammo, just aim, hold down the left mouse button and never let go.

This game has no tactics whatsoever, just run around and shoot everything that moves. The enemies are absolutely brain dead and the difficulty only comes to the fact that the game showers you in enemies. Wave after wave.

There's a few scripted story elements I like, but these are very few. Reznovs "flashback" was very fun since it reminded me of CoD World at War which is a game I like. The prison scene in the beginning is also very good.

Then comes the Hong Kong mission which is the low point of the game, absolutely atrocious. Just shoot, shoot, shoot because? I have no friggin idea. The Vietnam stuff is also mind boggingly dumb and rips off both Apocalypse Now and Deer Hunter. Complete with Fortunate Son playing in the speakers in an almost ironic way. Because that makes it authentic right? I was bursting out laughing all the time.

The game has tons of weapons, of course to practice for the Multiplayer part, but come on... an AK47 with a flamethrower? ARE YOU HIGH?! It also seems that they add way too modern weapons sometimes for 1968 or whenever the hell this game is suppose to take place. Homing rocket launchers? I don't think so.

The big plot twist could be seen from a mile away, but it doesn't matter. What matters is the awful, horrendous story telling. It's like playing a game made by 10 different teams which were stitched together in an ugly tapestry from hell. Nothing feels cohesive and the characters are so enormously gung ho one dimensional bland. "THE NUMBERS MASON!!!" ugh...

Awful, awful, awful
